review: This game is going to take control of you, the graphics are among the best in MOBAs. The community is, well, not as good as you would want it to be, but if you have friends you can play with, it doesn't matter as much. There are over 120 heroes to choose from and after 100+ hours you'll know all the things you need! Everything is available to you from the start so you can quickly master a few heroes and play on all pick if you want to, or play on single draft for additional challenge. There are also 8 gamemodes and a lot of events are coming out for nearly every festival eg. Christmas, Halloween etc. Overall, I recommend the game, it's great. If you want to learn the basics go play on bots for a while with a guide. Dota 2 gets a 9/10 from me just because of the community.

review: Felt like giving Dota 2 a try and like most other Moba games it's very addicting. I played a fair amount of the game as well as going through training. The heros were interesting and had a lot of diversity. Selecting the lane you preferring in hero select was a nice feature. That's the end of the good things I have to say about the game. Now for the bad. Still full of bugs. No good information on how to cancel auto buy resulting in odd issues with UI which you can't tell if it's a bug that prevents you from buying things and putting a large item icon on your screen. An insane amount of leavers during games. Then when you attempt to disconnect when it's safe, taking minutes for it to give you the disconnect screen. Region ques seem to be a joke. Always selected just the two North American ques and one in three matches getting multiple people who do not speak English. Pretty rediculus when this is supposed to be a game where you need to communicate with your team. This is also in addition to the very long que times. More time spent in que today then actually playing the game. This ultimately made me quit playing in digust. Summary- +Some great heros with unique abilities. +UI has great features when they work correctly. +Drop system that keeps you wanting to play. -Worst community I have ever had the displeasure of playing with. -Que times far too long. -Picking a region to play in doesn't seem to matter. -Though it's out of beta, still a large amount of bugs. -Training system needs some work.

game-hours: 1175.6
review: I love DOTA 2. It has quickly become my most-played game on Steam and I feel like I've barely scratched the surface of all there is to experience in it. Despite being limited to one map, the game still feels extremely large and always offers a brand new challenge with every match. With so many heroes to choose from, and so many crazy combinations for teams, I have a feeling that I'll still be learning the basics of this game for a long time coming. I can't write a DOTA review without mentioning the competitive aspect of the game. I'm a huge fan of esports, and have been following various scenes since 1997. I've watched the production values of these scenes increase slowly throughout the years to the point where there is enough media coverage and hype to reach nearly anyone. With DOTA2, I feel that things are taken to a whole new level. The in-game interface itself makes it very easy to view the latest big tournaments and watch them live from within the application WITH commentary. You can watch the games using a guided camera, or you can take control of the camera yourself and track your favorite player, all while the commentary is running in the background to give you constant updates of the action. It's phenomenal and it's another big reason why I'll be playing this game for years. In short, yes you should definitely give this game a try. No doubt about it.

review: Great MOBA. If you're into MOBAs like League of Legends, Smite, HoN, etc, then give this a try. It's free! And it's DAMN GOOD. First off, a warning: you're going to suck. Oh, you have some experience with MOBAs? Oh, in that case, you're going to suck and get pissed. Dota 2 has a pretty long learning curve. Loads of heroes to choose from and heaps of items to go along. The training system is a precious help and introduces you to the last hits, denies, shopping for items and combining items, allows you to play with a few noob-friendly (not easy and not weaker than the other ones, mind you, just not that complicated to master in the early stages of the game) heroes to get you to feel the game's pace. From then on, you still have a lot to learn. Everybody can use ALL heroes for free and there's no advantage anyone has over you except their own experience in the game. But there are plenty of heroes to go around and until you've played them all (or played against them) at least once, you'll be feeling like a noob when you face one for the first time. Dota 2 is rather unforgiving when it comes to carries. You die, you lose time, experience and GOLD. And you need GOLD to buy items to allow you to carry. Not that easy for supports either. Most of them do have the uppoer hand on some carries on the early stages of the game, but you need to know them in order to take advantage of that. Also, your abilities' damage doesn't really scale all that well to late game, where the carries start to shine. There are dozens of ward spots, jungling tricks and control points you need to master. Every game's different. Lanes are pretty unpredictable at Dota 2. You can have 2-1-2, but you can have a 1-1-3, a 1-2-2, or, if you have some jungler, you can have 1-1-1-2 os something like that. The game's pretty dynamic. Do check some guides and builds. They can help you in your first contacts with some heroes. But, hey... it's Dota 2. Everything's situational. Sure, there are a few core items on many heroes, but, all in all, it all depends on the game you're playing and a change can make ALL the difference. Again, if you're into MOBAs... Do try it. NOW!

game-hours: 455.2
review: Dota is a competitive game of action and strategy, played both professionally and casually by millions of passionate fans worldwide. Players pick from a pool of over a hundred heroes, forming two teams of five players. Radiant heroes then battle their Dire counterparts to control a gorgeous fantasy landscape, waging campaigns of cunning, stealth, and outright warfare. Irresistibly colorful on the surface, Dota is a game of infinite depth and complexity. Every hero has an array of skills and abilities that combine with the skills of their allies in unexpected ways, to ensure that no game is ever remotely alike. This is one of the reasons that the Dota phenomenon has continued to grow. Originating as a fan-made Warcraft 3 modification, Dota was an instant underground hit. After coming to Valve, the original community developers have bridged the gap to a more inclusive audience, so that the rest of the world can experience the same core gameplay, but with the level of polish that only Valve can provide.

review: Dota 2 is a game about getting fat, and whoever is the fattest of them all wins. If your 5 man fat orgy gets fatter faster than the other growing pile of mass on the other side of the map, then when these two hideous blobs of lard collide you'll still have some fat to toss around at the enemy while they scream at each other for not being fat enough. On the other hand when you're both at the weigh in and the other team's got some bigger numbers to boast about, you'll find yourself being smothered, crushed by the fat; it betrays you! They pull you in, absorbing you into their ever growing blob as your teammates are yelling to stop feeding their mass. It becomes increasingly apparent that you are not the fattest of them all, and you start to wonder why you ever started playing Dota 2 in the first place...

game-hours: 57.9
review: Dota 2 is hard, but there's a huge reward for those who commit. On the surface, the game is a like-for-like reproduction of the genre-creating (and still updated) Defense of the Ancients modification for Warcraft III, now transferred into Valve's Source engine. The game's punishing design is sometimes enough to drive you up the wall, but it's worth sticking the hours in: success in Dota 2 is about learning to effectively juggle both the broad strokes and finer details. If you're not aware of the basics of the burgeoning MOBA genre, two teams of five players spawn on corners of a map. Each team needs to work together with the goal of ultimately destroying a central structure--in Dota 2's case, the Ancient--in the opposing team's base. With most games lasting around the 40-minute mark, and occasionally edging past an hour, watching the enemy fortress dramatically crumble and sink to the ground feels like an exhilarating payoff. Aiding these two teams, named the Radiant and the Dire, are waves of AI assistants, called creeps. Batches of creeps spawn at 30-second intervals and charge merrily up the map's three pathways. In the clumps of remaining land lies a jungle, where numerous AI opponents spawn, offering lucrative benefits to players who take them on successfully. Finally, and in a bid to stop both teams from simply marching into one another's base, each team gets three powerful towers on each lane that easily shred through enemy players at the start of the game. Your individual ability to control and affect the rhythm of the game comes from how well you handle your hero. You mostly control a single unit in Dota 2, though there are exceptions: some heroes can summon controllable allies, such as bears, gargoyle babies, or wolves; one exceptionally versatile hero can split into three; and one item lets you take control of certain creeps. For each rule in Dota 2's impressive house-of-cards design, there's usually at least one character who completely ignores it, or finds a way around it via one of 130-odd items available from the in-match shop. For instance, try negating magic attacks with the black king bar, returning damage with the blade mail, or pounding out two ultimate abilities in quick succession with a refresher orb. The aim for most players is to accumulate as much gold and experience as possible, with income being delivered mostly by scoring the killing blow on enemy creeps and players. It's almost always easier to gang up on stray enemies as a group, which is why it's rarely a good idea to run about on your own. Then it's a case of splashing all your hard-earned money on some ultra-powerful items from the shop, while levelling up your base stats and abilities, and then clobbering the enemy team into submission via a few five-versus-five team fights. Rarely does it feel that simple, however. At the time of writing, 102 of the original Dota's 112 heroes have made their way into the sequel. Each hero has a handful of unique abilities and generally works best in a specific role, such as supporting other players as Omniknight, roaming around the map looking for opportunistic kills as Spirit Breaker, or evolving throughout the course of the game into an all-powerful vehicle of carnage and destruction as Phantom Assassin. There's only one map, unlike in many other MOBA titles, although Valve has not ruled out the addition of more over time, and has previously offered game-changing modes with seasonal events at Halloween and Christmas. But Dota 2's single sprawling map sets itself apart from the competition by being larger, more intricate, and packed with greater detail than the rest of the genre. Unlike in League of Legends, the jungle area is riddled with far more tangling pathways, the lanes feature additional shops selling exclusive items, and savvy players are given more opportunities to use the environment to hide, flee, and ambush their opponents. There are multiple layers of additional information that become increasingly relevant as you invest more time in the game. How do you effectively divide your forces? When should your team attempt to vanquish Roshan, the map's most powerful creep? What are runes? What's the significance of the fact that creeps get slightly stronger every seven and a half minutes? Often the game's dizzying scale is seen as off-putting or simply too complex, but the truth of Dota is that it can be entertaining as a new player to just sit down and let all those extraneous factors play out around you. Getting down to the brass tacks of the game with a group of like-minded friends is a lot of fun: start by buying your characters' recommended items, try your best not to get caught out of position, and get into the habit of buying observer wards. And watch out for Riki. As you'd expect from Valve, this is a beautifully presented game, with the Half-Life and Portal maker running victory laps around its competition in terms of UI, voice acting, and showing how to deftly add real personality to its characters. Only recently has the developer turned its attention to gently easing new players into the proceedings, however, and even now, mastering the basics feels like learning to swim by jumping in at the deep end. Efforts are being made to remedy this, though: right now there are a couple of tutorial levels, some well-designed AI bots, and a newbie playlist that restricts hero selection to just 20 of the most frequently picked characters. And with community-created hero guides now built directly into the game itself, Dota 2 is much easier to get started with than it has been in the past. Play a match every evening for a couple of weeks, and you start to see how Dota 2's wealth of disparate systems and mechanics combine into their own harmony, and you begin to understand how there are hundreds of elements that affect the game. Dota 2 is a tense war of accumulation and attrition. The biggest problem, which is coincidentally where the real excitement of the game lies, comes from struggling to process and interpret dozens upon dozens of mitigating circumstances while simultaneously trying to keep your cool. It is a complicated and exhausting game, and for the first few weeks, it's challenging just keeping up with the general rhythm of a match. But invest enough time into Dota 2, and you develop an almost unconscious ability to keep up with the game--performing actions such as sending the slightly fiddly in-game courier over to the faraway "secret" shop to get some rare items, for instance. After a couple of hundred hours of Dota 2, what once felt like spinning plates just happens automatically. Late-night Skype calls, drawn-out conversations down at the pub, and lost lunch breaks follow. Very few games can withstand so many emotionally charged discussions. When everything goes south, the psychological toll can be surprisingly intense, and this is very much a game with the power to both start and end close friendships. Dota 2 is an overwhelming, intoxicating, and emotionally dangerous game that can quite easily take over your entire gaming life. While Dota 2 has transferred the core of the original Dota into a cleaner, modern engine, the fact remains that losing is uniquely painful. Death in Dota 2 not only gives your opponent money, but robs you of some of your own and leaves you waiting up to a minute to respawn. By the time you've trudged back across the game's massive map--or spent money on a teleportation scroll--your opponent is now stronger and richer. Die two or three times in quick succession, which is easily done, and a match of Dota becomes a painful experience where you spend the next half hour getting bullied by an increasingly superior enemy. Other games in the genre have tried to mitigate this punishment, but Dota 2 positively revels in its complexities. The rich just get richer.

Double check all the words online, and you'll be fine. Special Thanks: To the wonderful community of students from South America and Russia looking to teach others how to communicate their animosity in a new language.

review: So you look at this game's store page and you're like "This looks like a fun game." So you download it and start it up. So you play a few games against bots and have fun, a few more against bots but with real people on your team. You're thinking "Wow this is a real fun team building game!" But you aren't ready to be up against real people you think so after training for a month and getting over a hundred hours played you think you're ready. You put down your prefrences: US West Server, English speaking people only, and you hop into a game. After six minutes you find a game (finally!) and after loading into the game you see your teammates' names.   38, ,  , and  . "Well those aren't English at all" you think to yourself, Your enemies all have English names though. Anyway into the game you go, 3 of your teamates go middle, 1 goes bottom and you are at top, there is no courier by the way. The 3 at mid are arguing in some language you don't understand and the one at bottom is afk. Within 10 minutes your team's T1 and T2 towers are gone, the enemies' towers aren't touched also   has just abandoned for being afk and in a few short minutes the others will abandon leaving you to be killed multiple times. The people on the other team are saying "I feel bad for you son" and other such things. After you lose you try another game, thinking that this one will be different. It's not. you try again and again look for a game that you aren't matched with foreign speakers that are terrible or you win so quickly and easily it's boring. But you never do, and you can't quit now you're to deep in. You've caught the bug, can't stop playing, you are devoted to finding that one game that isn't a disapointment, will you ever find it though? probably not. all in all it's a good game 10/10 would reommend.

review: Good
game-hours: 1175.6
review: I love DOTA 2. It has quickly become my most-played game on Steam and I feel like I've barely scratched the surface of all there is to experience in it. Despite being limited to one map, the game still feels extremely large and always offers a brand new challenge with every match. With so many heroes to choose from, and so many crazy combinations for teams, I have a feeling that I'll still be learning the basics of this game for a long time coming. I can't write a DOTA review without mentioning the competitive aspect of the game. I'm a huge fan of esports, and have been following various scenes since 1997. I've watched the production values of these scenes increase slowly throughout the years to the point where there is enough media coverage and hype to reach nearly anyone. With DOTA2, I feel that things are taken to a whole new level. The in-game interface itself makes it very easy to view the latest big tournaments and watch them live from within the application WITH commentary. You can watch the games using a guided camera, or you can take control of the camera yourself and track your favorite player, all while the commentary is running in the background to give you constant updates of the action. It's phenomenal and it's another big reason why I'll be playing this game for years. In short, yes you should definitely give this game a try. No doubt about it.

game-hours: 2353.7
review: It was one of the first big free-to-play games, and one of the first big multiplayer online battle arenas, or MOBAs. But going on five years later, League of Legends still holds firm as an example of excellence. With its amazing variety of Champions, rewarding progression systems, and fast but intensely strategic team play, it easily hooked me and refused to let go. That addictiveness and competitive spirit, combined with a generous free-to-play approach and frequent updates from developer Riot Games, has created one of the biggest and liveliest gaming communities anywhere. Like most MOBAs, League of Legends main attraction is its five-on-five matches on its staple three-lane map. Called Summoner's Rift, this map is brightly and colorfully designed, and it creates a distinct playstyle with the way its dense brush allows you to conceal yourself and surprise enemies. I particularly love how the distinctive jungles on either side of the central river are filled with NPC monsters that give buffs to players who take a break from battle to go on the hunt  its a constant temptation to risk venturing into the other teams territory to attempt to steal their buffs. The choice between engaging the other team directly or attacking their resources allows for interesting strategies and depth beyond simply fighting until one Champion or turret is dead. Inside each team's base also lies an Inhibitor which, if destroyed, causes the opposing teams side to start spawning super minions. Its an extra strategic objective to target in the enemy base, and having one more building to take down often leads to exciting and game-ending team fights. From Ziggs, the bomb-loving little rat, to Jinx, the blue-pigtailed maniac, its electrifying to coordinate with your team to mow down your opponents and push lanes with Leagues Inside each team's base also lies an Inhibitor which, if destroyed, causes the opposing teams side to start spawning super minions. Its an extra strategic objective to target in the enemy base, and having one more building to take down often leads to exciting and game-ending team fights. As free-to-play games go, League of Legends is a model of generosity. Though it doesnt give everything away like Dota 2 does, it serves up a weekly rotating selection of 10 Champions for free, and you can purchase and play with any of the 117-character roster for a reasonable price of between two and eight dollars each. Yes, that adds up to a princely sum if you intend to buy every single character, but theres no need to buy more than you intend to actually play. The Champion rotation is a nice way to try before you buy, and helped me to pace myself by learning just a few characters at a time. You can also unlock every Champion at a satisfying rate without spending a penny, which is not only fulfilling, but it sets League apart from the type of free-to-play game that deliberately makes it impractical to play at a competitive level for no cost. Since many players opt for a completely free experience, its exciting when the roster changes and pushes the community to try out fresh characters and new strategies. If you want to go a step further, you can buy cosmetic skins for every character. They can be pricey, but each skin has tons of detail, and its impressive that most of them come with unique spell effects and animations. My Panda Annie skin, for example, changes the little pink-haired girl into a mini-geisha of sorts, and her ultimate ability calls down a panda version of her grizzly bear, Tibbers. (Yay, Tibbers!) In the opening minutes of a match, League's Champions distinguish themselves with lots of low-level area-of-effect abilities that make killing minions quick and easy. Unlike some other MOBAs, there's no way to attack your own minions to deprive your enemy the experience and gold, making it simpler to focus on other tasks, like getting last hits. The absence of those denial tactics definitely takes a competitive aspect away from League, but it's one that's often frustrating. I dont miss it. Relative to other MOBAs where management of special-ability juice (magic points, in this case) is key, I also enjoy how often abilities are available for use in League. Its awesome being able to constantly harass opponents with spells rather than having to worry about conserving them all for one crucial moment. But that doesnt mean abilities dont matter. Some of the strongest attacks are skill shots (projectiles requiring precise manual aim), and failing to hit your target can have catastrophic, game-changing consequences in team fights. From simple slows to huge Super Mega Death Rockets that travel across the whole map, snagging enemies with these moves while dodging theirs is a giddy thrill. The importance League of Legends places on these skill shots helps set its style of action apart. You dont lose any money when you die in League, making it easier to save up for new weapons and armor in the item shop. The item selection is decent, but most players always seem to rely on you to build your character using expected items, like The Bloodthirster or Rabadon's Deathcap. Straying from the recommended builds doesn't make you useless, but some of these might as well be called required items instead of recommended, considering their power. On the bright side, this means spending less time shopping and more time playing. Also, the recent addition of a variety of Support items, like The Frost Queens Claim and Talisman of Ascension which grant passive gold, are a good move in the right direction for diversifying builds. It might be easier to coordinate unusual item builds if League had built-in voice chat. Unless youve set up a TeamSpeak/Ventrilo/Mumble/Skype/etc call with your pre-arranged team before joining a game, the only ways to communicate are via text, which often goes unnoticed, or through four alerts to indicate danger, on my way, missing, or assist me. Nothing sucks more than watching a crucial surprise attack slip through my fingers because a teammate was too busy to see me pinging. At least when your team falls so hopelessly behind 20 minutes into a 40-ish minute match that four of five teammates agree its all over, the handy surrender option prevents you from wasting time fighting a losing battle. Even though you play on the same few maps with similar items, theres so much depth and strategy going on that no two matches of League of Legends ever feel the same. Its distinctive style encourages surprise attacks and frequent use of skill-shot powers, and its colorful art style makes everything pop on the screen. Learning how to make the most of its characters and to become an asset to a team is a long and challenging process, but once youve got it down, its incredibly satisfying to work together to destroy your enemies in this amazing MOBA.

review: dota (defense of the ancients ) is a action rts game, a great esports platform, a fun game to play if you just know the mechanics of this great game. 10 random players choose from a strong hero pool with different powers and the players have to cooperate with each other understand the extremities of the game. Leadership,Forgivness,Sacrifice and great strategy is required for the win or you end up losing and wasting an hour or two. The only drawback is a steep learning curve but when finally you learn this game you will just love this and play all day. It is also a great way to connect with players of the world a large community supports this, So a word of advice PLAY HARD DIE HARD GO PRO.

review: This game shouldn't be ignored if you're not a casual gamer. Just like every other valve game: Exelent! + Generous "Free to play" system + Extremly teambased game (Teamplay decides mostly the victory) + Every round is different = Very long playable + Customisation + Sound, music and voices + Epic feeling/atmosphere + Pro gaming orientated + Private matches + Bots are exactly following their difficulty (easy bots are easy, impossible bots are your nightmares) and are intelligent + Many characters, who are voiced to show that they have a personality and backstory. Every character is different to another. They react/express themselves with the kills, deaths, team mate characters, enemy characters (espicially Kunkka and Tidehunter, Clockwerk and Tinker, Crystal Maiden and Lina("You were adopted"), etc. ) + Roles (Carry, Support, Lane-Support, Disabler, Ganker, Nuker, Initiator, Jungler, Pusher, Roamer, Durable) +/- Steep learning curve: Depends if you like an intense game or not. - One map - One gamemode - Some players are not playing in their local server - Low on polygons Remember: The difficulty of this game is high and frustrating, but as soon as you mastered it, you'll be rewarded with great games.

review: I just want to start with, that this is one of the best games I've EVER played. The first RTS-esque game I ever touched, was Warcraft III. I remember playing it together locally with my big brother and a friend of ours. So my brother, fell for this game; League of Legends, too at the time I was a big fan of the musician with the name of Basshunter. So I had to try LoL too, it was free, what had I to loose? My interest for it. Right away. It wasn't as action-filled, or exciting like the games I played at that time; Minecraft and Call of Duty(sorry). So yeah, I was more the 'FPS-guy'. But about a year later, a friend of mine got a free BETA-copy of the game, Dota 2. He wasn't especially good at it, and probably ruined a game or two for his teammates, though it sure was fun! A other friend of mine got it from him, it was nothing special about it, but after all, they started to play together. A day, when a friend was over on a sleep-over, he had this bunch of copies of the game, so I asked him, might I have one? And he said yes, like it was obvious. Eventhough I only had watched the cinematic trailer(which was damn awesome) and listened to Basshunters song, it felt damn promising. And finally, my to already-playing mates, invited me to play a match. My first hero was Sven. I picked him for his looks, but he was a truly badass character, now Sven is my personal favorite, and best played hero. Well... I suppose the game didn't go so well, and I lost my hopes for it. But a month later, I was back in the track; and I enjoyed every single second of that match. The akward satisfication I felt inside when I was auto-attacking creeps. Now I play Dota 2 alot... ALOT. And I felt since September this year, I've felt that I've learned alot by watching pro-matches, professional players like Purge, and by playing the game in general. Being a pro-player is a target I really want to reach, which I think is worth going for. Dota 2 is a very fun and competetive game that has its up and downs, but is pure entertaintment.

review: This game wont make anyone bored... I have playing Dota 2 for almost 920 hours and i never get bored ~ even if it the same map and the same concept. this game combine strategy and team work and skills all at once, timing and knowledge of the items... players in lvl 1 can beat lvl 200 ~ everyone here is equal and all the heroes are free to play. i think this game is the best yet i found that i can still play it all the time and never get bored cuz everytime i try something new~ new hero ~ new strategy ~ new items ~ and every time its new party to play with and a new combination of heros that you can try to combine the skills with. Most of the people see a MOBA game and just wont start to play it cuz they see the gameplay looks from the top (watch the character from up) and they think the game sucks~ i think its what makes that game a good game... you be able to watch your back and looks out for your friends. There also the option the add mods from workshop and get the game more funny adn try new stuff. Also you can play with different mode like : "least played" or "all random" and its make the choices of the heros more fun to play and learn (and the game mode have alot of options). I recommend everyone to play dota 2 and more recommend to play with friends and talk while the game... just keep positive feelings and be happy when you play ~ its just a game XD

review: A freshly released new MOBA game thats currently the most played game on steam- Dota 2. A sequel to its great successor - Defense of the Ancients. A wide variety of dedicated server selection by regions will merely make a difference as the game is flooded with russians. Oh, you thought you had it bad at HoN or LoL? Prepare to rip your balls off when you realize that on US servers 3 of your teammates are from russia. PRIVET. While you rage at your teammates youll constantly have this feeling at the back of your head - if russians run from russian servers how bad is it there? Pretty god damn bad I assume. If you manage to team up with 4 of your friends the game is quite enjoyable. Wide variety of heroes will constantly keep you entertained aswell as interesting additions to the droppable item pool that allow stat tracking and changing appearances of heroes of your choice in game. A splendid graphics and physics engine makes Dota 2 currently the best game of its genre. 9/10.

In a large bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, salt and sugar. Make a well in the center and pour in the milk, egg and melted butter; mix until smooth. 2. Heat a lightly oiled griddle or frying pan over medium high heat. Pour or scoop the batter onto the griddle, using approximately 1/4 cup for each pancake. Brown on both sides and serve hot.

review: If I want to give a review of this game in a nutshell, it would look like this: "The game is good, the community of players is bad, unforgiving and unwelcoming." First of all: if you don't want to play something, in which players become insulting-machines saying their favourite words "noob, feeder, report", then don't play this game, because you will turn into a nervous-wreck person in a short time, and will find yourself already punished just because you are a beginner, who just completed the tutorials. All of this because the players take this game bloody serious, and they can't play for fun, but only to get kills, and win the round. So I warned you: if you want to even try this game's pvp out, then you should have a lot of patience. (and with that, I mean A LOT) Now let's get into the game itself: Note: if you already played League of Legends, then you may think, that is all the same. Well, partly it's true, partly it isn't. Dota (2) and LoL may have the same goal, but they are actually very different in game mechanics, rules, and some other things too. Believe me, I've tried both games. /Note Unfortunately, the first DotA wasn't in my life, even tough I did play Warcraft 3. So yes, I still realized the changes for some heroes' look, and found some of them, who I liked to use in WC 3 (insert a short smile). Personally, I like this game. Even tough, I have an old pc, on which the graphics looks awkward (with missing textures even from the map), the game can be runned, and played well. The game sets on only one map, but with more than a hundred playable heroes, this only map can become re-playable for a very long time (I still would like to see more maps in the future). I don't really know, what more could I say about the game itself. Now did I say, that I like this game? Yes, I actually did, because itself is pretty good and spectacular. However, there is something, that makes me very disappointed: the player-community. And I don't want to say anything more about it, since I've already told a lot about it, in the beginning. I'll still recommend it, because the game isn't guilty to have that harrassing and unwelcoming community.

game-hours: 1565.9
review: You think LoL is better? Get out, why? They're both MOBA's, don't compare them just because of that. LoL and DotA2 are both great games. (I've been playing LoL recently) Dota 2 (Defense of the Ancients 2) is a fantastic MOBA game where teamwork is highly recommended, you have your three lanes where you and your laning partner (unless you're middle, although you can duo-lane with IO or tri-laning) try to win the lane against the other team's laning heroes, this is what we call 'Early game' or the laning phase. Later on you will often roam around the map in order to help your allies get kills, usually after a few kills have been made and your team has nice farm (nice amount of gold/nice items), this is called 'Mid Game' And then beyond that point when you're near lvl18-25 is known as 'Late Game/End Game' where you will usually be close to destroying the enemy team's ancient. And then there's the classic "Base Race", that's when there are no towers or barracks defending the ancient on either team meaning its a race to end each others ancient first. Note: This is my first proper review and I did it half-heartedly as I just wanted to get back to the game itself. I want more people to like this. Here is music for you to listen to while you MOBA

review: I do not want to be a troll, but recently I have left behind LoL to start playing DOTA2, and I do not regret this decision, since it has more in-depth at every fight when compared to LoL. Sure the community seems a bit more toxic then LoL's but I can get used to it, since all the time I do not write in chat and mute the flamers and wannabe's. Playing with friends it's more fun then alone and more rewarding, especially the events or being in a team. One thing I do not like about the game is the cost of the skins and items for the events. They are way to pricey. But on the other hand there is always discounts at the shop. To mention that the graphics are amazing and optimized since it is running on the SOURCE engine. See you on the battlefield champion! PS: If you want to do SOLO rankings prepare to learn Russian and how to delete DOTA from Steam. Do that at your own risk but I strongly suggest playing with friends.

game-hours: 4001.7
review: An excellent alternative to Rosetta Stone. During your first 100 hours you can expect to learn how to communciate with and insult people in multiple different languages including - but not limited to - Russian (!!!!), Brazilian (CALA BOCAAAA), and multiple Chinese dialects (). If you enjoy playing games that rely heavily on communication with people who don't speak a word of English (noop) despite selecting US East (South America North) or US West (Russia East) as their prefered server then dota is the game for you. The learning curve is steep so make sure not to give up if you don't do well during your first few games. Improve quickly by selecting a hero by slamming your face into the keyboard, calling mid lane, and using all your spells to quickly kill the creep. Don't forget that you can buy kitty ears from the in-game store to make your favorite character look cuter and give the illusion that you are good at the game.

review: The game inappropriately titled 'Defence of the Ancients (two)'- you do not defend ancients, but participate in a deathmatch game similiar to Call of Duty- is a blight on gaming. After playing the game for two and a half years I feel as though a malignant tumor has spawned within my brain, and it is growing. Gaben 'Icefrog' Newell (the 'genius' of the game) is praised as a God amongst the community, however, 'he' is actually a Succubus, conspiring with the other succubi to obtain the blood of the virgins whom entertain themselves with the game. Nevertheless, the game does have several redeeming factors. Firstly, the game will allow you to expand your vocabularly as when controlling a hero, they speak in a bloviated manner - using large words as if they were free. Phrases such as "I am a beacon of knowledge blazing across a black sea of ignorance" and not to mention the hero lores. Here is an exert from the currently titled (undoubtly going to change again) Outworld Devour's lore: "Imprinted deep in the shining lattices of his intellect lies a resonant pattern akin to prophecy, a dark music implying that eventually some evil will wake out there, beyond the edges of creation, and turn its attention to our world." Like what the  does that mean? It doesn't matter though, as I have benefited from things such as this by implementing them into essays. Secondly, the game allows you to socialize with fellow autists, forming a kind of autist convention where everyone discusses memes such as "S A D B O Y S" and "KOTL, Giff me Mana." This imminently creates a circle-jerk of a large magnitute. This is great however as you get to see some  & Balls Anyway,  game.

review: Let me start this review saying that I like DotA, I've played a good amount of time, if you like strategy games, you'll probably like DotA 2. So why won't I recommend it? Simply. The community sucks. Hard. if you convince a friend to play and don't want him to give up, you must play with him in private lobbies, practice with him, teach him how to play each role properly etc. My girlfriend tried to play, she gave up after being heavilly insulted 2 times in a row because she made some mistakes... If you don't have experience with this kind of game (I don't like the term MOBA, but, yeah, games like League of Legends or Heroes of Newearth) be warned though, you MUST practice, watch videos about each hero and know your role if you want to have some fun when playing online. But for me, it doesn't matter how much I practice, I always end up in the same team with angry boys who can't enjoy the game because you are not playing the way he likes, so, after some time, I discovered it was better to play against bots with my friends.

game-hours: 691.0
review: My mild mannered, canadian friend got angry enough to call someone a nig**r. A long time casual acquaintance completely freaked out at me when I swapped positions with him at an inopportune moment. People get angry with me when I pick my favorite hero (Phantom Assassin), because she is somewhat mediocre and not used very much in professional play. People get angry with me when I don't pick Phantom Assassin, because she's the hero I've played most and have the highest winrate with. More than half of my games feature someone who does not speak English, or is muted. Earlier today I played a game where my team captain drafted me Crystal Maiden, and was confused when I complained about her poor, crippled appendages. She takes like a second to raise her staff and fire a super slow snowball at someone, walks around agonizingly slowly, and turns at the speed of a small locomotive. When I try to explain that this bothers me to people, they react with a curious mixture of confusion and horror. This is the dota experience, and changing it is unthinkable. I introduced two of my better friends in real life to the game. I think that one of them was more despairing during a game we played, than when his last girlfriend split up with him. But still, they play.

review: Oh man, Dota 2. Don't get me wrong here at the negative review, hear me out first. I say with confidence that Dota 2 is an addicting MOBA game with great gameplay and fun. Then why the negative review you say? Well for one the community is scarcely better than Russia under Stalin. If you play on any server you must be 100% prepared for racism, s, jerks, and 12 year olds. Not only that, but even if you put your language preference as English, half the players you play with are obnoxious Peruvians. This does not make the game unplayable but can seriously piss you off. If you have played this game as long or longer than me you will understand this. Another bad thing is that I would willingly compare playing this game to a adrug addiction. You literally can't stop playing it when you start, and when life interrupts you, you will start to think Dota 2 is more important. THAT MY FRIENDS IS WHEN YOU QUIT THE GAME! I had to wean myself off of it for like weeks until I couldn't stand looking at the icon anymore, needless to say I uninstalled. game-hours: 1292.8
review: I've been playing DOTA since DOTA 1 came up a decade ago. In DOTA 2, the game mechanic is quite balanced, every hero has its own strengths and weaknesses just like in the previous one. Definitely not a P2W kind of game. However, the solo MMR pairing is really awful. I dropped from 3k to 2k in just a week and forever stuck in this level no matter how hard I play. Here's a few suggestions that I could think of: -They should also consider hours of playing and K/D/A ratio instead of just MMR level to balance the pairing. -Players who got into low priority should get more severe punishment (e.g. longer period and add extra requirements to get away from low priority) so they would think twice before they trash-talk and not obidient. At this rate, a skill in par with TI players' is the only way to break out. Unfortunately, you need to play A LOT to get there. If you're really lucky, you could be paired with decent players, and that's a one big if. A casual gamer like me has no place in this game.

game-hours: 178.4
review: Dota 2 is a similar game to League of Legends, with some differences that make both of them unique, like how you can get couriers and have access to secret shops in dota while in LoL, there are summoner spells and masteries. However, this is a review about Dota and what the game is about, not a comparison about these 2 games. Dota is a MOBA game (Multiplayer Online Battle Arena), in which you are place in a team of 5 players to go against another team of 5 players with one main object, which is to obliterate the enemies towers, barracks, and finally, their ancient. All of you start at level 1 and all of you have to destroy anything in your path while trying to not have any casualties along the way, since the enemy who just killed you will gain lots of exp as well as some gold. As simple as it looks, it's not, as that there are many ways that your opponent can stop you from progressing, like the occasional ganks that happen from time to time. Aside from the basics of Dota, the game is really fun......unless there's that *sshole that'll keep calling you a noob or if there's that player that dies intentionally, but other then that, the graphics are good, controls are easy, and overall, the gameplay is great, so go on and download Dota and have fun.

game-hours: 936.3
review: I've played this game since it was a mod for Warcraft, and I have to say, it's one of my favorite games. However, much like TF2, it has it's fair share of problems. For starters, this game has a stupidly high learning curve. There's no one true way to play any of the 100+ heroes, and it can get very frustrating very fast trying to find what you can easily work with for any of them with the gigantic selection of items. Other than Legion Commander, I still have yet to master any of the very small pool of heroes that I feel comfortable playing as, with my success {or lack there of, which is normally the case} depending largely on the skill level of the enemy team and my teammates. Which brings us to the next point. 90% of the people who play this game are stupid. Now, I don't claim to be good at this. I'm slightly above average at best. However, it's hard to play on anything outside of solo bot servers when you're constantly thrown in with stupid people, first timers, people who don't speak the server regions language, people who are only there to prance around in costumes, or don't want to follow simple orders/use common sense. Or any combination of the above. Meanwhile, you can rest assured that your opponents will almost always have their act together, and be an unstoppable force that you futiley try to at least hinder. Which is made even harder when your teammates insist on throwing themselves into unwinnable battles, further feeding them until the point where there's a 10+ level gap between you and the lowest leveled enemy. On the other hand, you might go up against a team that's super bad. As in, it's a game that lasts less than 20 minutes. In which case, you've learned nothing, and your time is wasted just as thoroughly as it would be against people out of your league. Or, on the occasion that you get teammates that know what they're doing, you can expect them to whine about your choice of hero, your starting items/abilities, your lane choice, or god forbid, your costume. At which point, 9/10 of these people will purposefully feed the enemy or go afk, and then either rage quit or stop when you've ceased your apparantly unforgivable behavior. Or they might report you to try and get you thrown into low priority {more on that below}, which is Dota's equivalent of hell {long connection times, and having to play with the worst of the worst}. And unlike TF2, you can't just drop out whenever you wish without taking a heavy penalty for doing so. So have fun being in matches where there will be almost no fun a majority of the time. Now, there is a report system, which in theory, is supposed to shoo away the vermin that don't need to be playing this in the first place. In practice, it's horribly broken, due to being automated. Doing amazingly good, but you're the odd man out in a Peruvian 4 stack that you've somehow managed to offend? Expect to have the low priority message pop up when you exit to the menu after the match. Or maybe you want to report that 0/25 Treant that refused to do his job, and started purposely dying to feed the enemy. The entire server could report him, but he could still easily slip through without getting lp. In all seriousness, it's down to luck if it does work when you want it to, and doesn't when it's being abused. Up next, hero balance. Thankfully, this isn't quite as bad as it could be, but there is still silliness here and there. Some heroes have one or two overpowered abilites, while others are all around unbalanced, and others still are in sore need of buffing. At the same time, some heroes are nicely balanced, but are easily outclassed by other heroes who can perform the same role, only much better and easier. Why pick Legion Commander and eventually outdamage the enemy team using skill, when you can pick Ursa and outdamage them from level 3 onwards and rarely have to press more than one button? Why pick Weaver and alternate between your 2 escapes when you can pick Storm Spirit and have an escape with no cooldown? Why pick Centaur Warrunner to be durable when you can pick Axe and not only be durable, but be so durable the lane gets locked down for your enemy? There's tons of examples like this. Also, you'll see some heroes almost every match, {Pudge, Sniper, Zeus, who all have skills that can be more or less mindlessly spammed/have low risk high reward playstyles.} but lots are seen either rarely, or rarely outside of comp play {Io, Meepo, Dark Seer, who all take some degree of skill/have high risk decent reward playstyles}. What it sadly boils down to is, why play a hero where you have more than 1 button to press and risk being overwhelmed but have a more rewarding experience, when you can pick a hero that more or less does the same thing, but with less complexity? As with TF2, Valve is slowly but surely turning this into another hat simulator. I played a ton of the original Dota, and I sure don't remember any customization, because that would have been silly. This game is hard enough without being distracted by someones super pimped out loadout, or worrying if you're going to get a nice drop {if any, only 2-3 people usually get drops at the end of the round}. The main problem with character customization though, is that much like TF2, it attracts half wits that only want to play the super easy classes and dress them up, then look down on everyone else who isn't wearing a 20c wolf hat. Yeah, take your little wolf hat into a ranked match. See how they like it. Also like TF2, Valve focuses more on cosmetic items than the game itself, which started off small, but in recent months has led to them: 1. Canceling popular gamemodes, in order to {in thier own words} 'focus more on cosmetic sets'. 2. Building entire gamemodes around expensive sets {although in fairness, said sets only enhanced the modes/tracked stats for them, but still...}, or just flatout making new modes pay to win {the Year Beast Brawl was p2w to the point that disgusting amounts of money trumped good old fashioned skill almost 100% of the time}. 3. Doing inane things like changing the perfectly fine models of heroes, and then using that as an excuse to make more money {Shadow Fiend's model was just fine, but then he got a redesign that looked like an angsty 12 year old made it, and a $35 cosmetic that looked like an even more angsty 10 year old designed it}. 4. Possibly the worst, outright ignoring critical server issues {as in, thousands of people having issues even launching the game critical} to focus on cosmetic item bugs. Overall, the game would be greatly improved if Valve would do the following things: 1. Mandatory region locking for everyone, keeping Americans in America, Russians in Russia etc etc, thus heavily cutting down on the amount of people not knowing a regions language. 2. A proper tutorial for new players. 3. Making the above tutorial mandatory, as well as making only solo bot matches possible until a certain player level is reached. 4. Heavy improvement on the report system, to prevent the constant abuse of it, and to make sure it works when it legitimately needs to be used. 5. Rather than adding new costumes every other week, finally adding the other heroes from the mod, along with some much needed balancing for all the heroes. As fun as this game is, I reccomend it to no one, other than someone willing to go through absolute misery to occasionally have fun.
game-hours: 3140.9

game-hours: 3399.1
review: ing Addicting! =) Well Played to the developers and to every who contributes to the future of the game!
game-hours: 1934.8
review: A really fun and strategic game. Unlike any other moba games, this game is free- and not pay to win. You can choose any hero from the hero pool, which is around 100ish if I am not mistaken. This allow for more variety. There are many hero. Some are complex while some are beginner friendly. For example, I find Abaddon quite easy but effective to use, mainly because of its ultimate that acts like a heal shield. However I only have played this game for a really short time(14 hours) and I have yet to try all of the heroes. Among that I have tried is: Abbaddon, Sven, Dazzle, Slark and Venomancer. There are many types of heroes in the game. Carry, Nuker,disabler,iniator and many more. I like the variety this game offer- and also the factor of fun. Dota 2 also requires teamwork and patience, by only attacking the enemy tower without strategy is almost considered as suicide. There are also lane, which is divided to: Middle,Upper and bottom. Usually heroes are tasked to go to certain lane- to farm for gold and get items which are really game changing, especially if you use a carry. There are also a ancient which need to be destroyed to win the game. Also most payed items is merely cosmetic only. They make you heroes look cooler but doesn't give any advantage. There are also other cosmetic items such as Courier, Hud,ticket and keys that doesn't give any ingame advantages and merely cosmetic. Although the Dota 2 has some weakness, Dota 2 has given me a fun and epic experience. I will continue to play Dota 2 and hopefully this game will keep improving. Verdict: 9.5/10

review: This Coming from a League of Legends player : Pros : - Punishing Gameplay (can be consider con but it's more challanging this way) - Denying creeps - Couriers - You can stack jungle creeps - Bigger map means more fog of war (which mean you can juke more) - Teleportation scrolls - Aegis Of immortal - All Heroes are free - No Runes and Masteries - You can see what the enemies is picking, which mean you can counter them (can be con, because enemies will try to counterpicked you too) - Is more customizable with many cosmestics such as Hud, loading screens, announcer, etc - Have items drops - The invoker Cons : - You'll lose money when you die - No Recall, which means you have to walk back or buy a town portal scrolls - No jungle buffs like blue or red (can be pros) - Is easier to make mistakes here and harder to come back - No surrender vote (can be pros when you wreck your enemy and vice versa) - Most heroes' mana pool is fairly low and have a skill that cost high mana - No summoner's spells - Item doesn't boost your skill's damage (can be pros) League Of Legends and Dota 2 are both great games and are my favorite game of all time, with both are highly competitive and required a strong teamwork. Both game are free, so you can play as much as you like, so have fun and don't forget. SPIN 2 WIN

review: Heres the thing that makes life so interesting. The theory of evolution claims that only the strong shall survive. Maybe so...maybe so...But the theory of competition says just because their the strong doesn't mean they cant get their 's kicked. Thats right. See what every long shot, come from behind underdog will tell you is this. The other guy may in fact be the favorite, the odds maybe stacked against you, fair enough. But what the odds don't know is this isn't a math test. This is a completely different kind of test. One where PASSION has a funny way of trumping logic. So before you step up to the starting line, before the whistle blows, and the clock starts ticking. Just remember out here the results don't always add up. No matter what the stats may say, and the experts may think, and the commentators may have predicted, when the race is on all bets are off. Don't be surprised if someone decides to flip the script and take a pass on yelling uncle. And then suddenly as the old saying goes, WE GOT OURSELVES A GAME!

game-hours: 1925.4
review: just one more game.... I know this is the 5th time I said it! I don't really believe it anyway either! This is easily one of the best Free-to-Play games. It is NOT free-to-win or anything like that. Nothing you buy has ANY effect on the gameplay. You are essentially paying just to play dress-up with your characters (and you get those items for free through playing anyway!) It is a HUGE game, and you WILL SUCK HORRIBLY at first. Choose a fairly simple hero (probably a support first) and learn how they work before you switch heroes. WATCH THE PROS! There are some free games and tournaments to watch and learn how the game is played and they are actually FUN TO WATCH. The community is probably 40-60 between welcoming players and A$$holes. Make friends with the good ones and keep playing with them, or better yet play with some of your REAL friends and suck horribly together! After about 300-1000 hours of playing, you might only suck a bit, though you'll probably still suck pretty bad. By that point there's no turning back -- you will be a DOTA2 player for life! and it will be GLORIOUS! The only people I would NOT reccommend this to are: people with limited time (games average 25-45 mins and can go past an hour) people who get frustrated easily or let the griefers get to them (thin skin will do you in!) people who can't communicate or like to do things their own way -- this is THE TEAM GAME. Listen to your team to win, or listen to your team  you out.

review: Dota 2 is a sequel to the Defense of the Ancients (DotA) Warcraft III: Reign of Chaos and Warcraft III: The Frozen Throne mod., Developed by Valve Corporation, Designed by none other than IceFrog and distributed by Steam. I was a DotA player previously and shifted to DOTA 2 just before the The International Dota 2 Chamionship 2012, after I got beta invite from Steam. DotA players will love Dota 2 because of IceFrog and his concept and designs and its very similar to DotA but with added attractions and customization. If you have played DotA in your past you can very well know what the game is all about, but if you haven't, don't worry, DOTA 2 has got your back. You get training and how to play and all you need to know In-Game. Its a free to play game, but I think its about time to change that and make people buy this game just because its worth buying. So, what are you thinking? Just download the game and start playing. Make friends and teams online or ask your friends to join alongside yourself. Just Remmeber : Every player you come across in game is there to have fun and enjoy the game like yourself. So, please keep the gaming spirit alive and don't forget to enjoy and have fun. Hope you guys like my review and start playing this game soon. See you all in game.

review: I never liked games like league of legends or smite, but Dota 2 is a whole new story. It is absolutely a great and addictive game to play. The character selection is massive compare to LOL. It is more complicated than League of Legends, so it will take more time learning the game. Some differences between the two games are: 1) couriers that bring you items instead of walking to base to get it 2) you have to buy Town scrolls to teleport back to base. 3) you can "deny" creeps. ( killing your own creeps so your opponent gets less gold and exp) 4) if you die, you lose gold and is harder to comeback from 5) in game voice chat 6) "pause" key to halt the game if you need something. ( anybody can unpause regardless of who paused it) Based off my experience in this game, i haven't encounter much "ragers". I get the occasional one here and there, but not as often as League of legends. Update: Ever since i started doing ranked matches, there have been more "ragers" and non-english speakers. It was frustrating at times, but I got over it. If you don't like the bad side of this game's community, i suggest getting friends to queue up with you. Don't have friends that play dota? Make new friends during your games. You'd be surprise at how nice some people are in games. Don't worry too much about the Haters. Let them hate, while you enjoy a good time playing dota. Online games will always have some haters, especially games that involves a lot of teamwork. Based off my experience in this game, i haven't encounter much "ragers". I get the occasional one here and there, but not as often as League of legends.

game-hours: 12.5
review: This is AWESOME game.
game-hours: 495.2
review: I've spent 435 hours in this game at the time of this review. That equates to roughly 18 days, or just over half a month. It is far and away my most played game on Steam (my next most played game is TF2 with 150-some hours), which doesn't even compare. This game is hard. Possibly the most complicated thing I've ever done in these 18 days is walking in front of NPC units as they walk across the map and stopping periodically so that they have to stop to - thereby allowing me to attack the enemy's units at a safer area relative to my side of the map. This game is more than just a game I play - I can also watch games from within the client, both from my friends and from professional DotA 2 teams. The International, a Valve-created tournament held in Seattle, will this year have a prizepool of over TEN MILLION dollars (mostly funded by the community). The hats and other accessories in this game are also spectacular - I sometimes wonder whether I'm playing a game where I viciously kill different creatures on a battlefield, or one where I play dress-up with oddly disfigured digital dolls. Although if you don't want to spend your days getting flamed you should probably pick up this game at the same time as four other friends. tl;dr - Community (at least in the metagame) is good. Valve is good. Game is great. Play with friends.

review: You want to make friends and have no real means to do so? Well look no more!Dota 2 is the latest social platform specialized in connecting you with others(mainly russians).No matter where you're from or on which server you play EU-West,East,Asia,US you will have the opportunity to make friends. The players and the community in general are extremely friendly and they will make you feel loved and appreciated. If you are a new player and do not play to the best of your ability, your team will always try to help you and encourage you do do better.They will use certain words to motivate you and let you know your well being means a lot to them. Honestly, I have almost 1000 hours in Dota 2 and I've spent at least 950 of them chatting with people.I even quit mIRC since Dota 2 was released.If you purchsed the compendium you have some visual emotes which the IRC didn't have.You don't have to use the plain, boring :) to show them you are smiling, you can use FACES THAT EXPRESS EMOTIONS INSIDE THE GAME.Talk about next-gen. Best social interaction platform ever since MSN messenger!Highly recommended!

review: It's a great game. I highly recommend it because of the amount of variety. It gives you over 50.. no.. over 100 combinations of characters and items to use in battle. In Dota 2 you rely both on strategy and strength, and in some cases, even teamwork. But there are some few drawbacks, for example, there's only 1 map and finding an online game in some regions takes several minutes. ( Or at least, that is my case ). But still, the design of characters, effects and models, compared to the ones from Dota 1, are fascinating. I really like the new heroes' look. Plus, it's not like you really have to pay for useful weapons and items. You can buy things in-game, in map shops to strengthen your hero, and even your team. I really give this game a HIGH ranking!

game-hours: 101.1
review: Dota2 is something more than a game. It is a test. But that let my comment put you off. What lays under this very intricate, complex game is and experience you won't get anywhere else. It raises the bar on teamwork in multiplayer games. Because without teamwork you'll surely fail. And that is something a lot of multiplayer games try and fail with the self appointed hero player trying to show off. Each member, including the NPC are important. The controls, the interface will be daunting and put most people off, like me for instance. Because the game itself is 'INSTENSE' from the get go! But once you get use to the heroes you can play as, the lingo and system, that instensity that put you off, will drive you. Dota2 is more than just a game, it's a sport. And with all sports, you can make a great hobby out of it. You can have great fun. Or you can go pro. Oh! And it's FREE!!! Give it a go and don't be put off.

review: I avoided MOBAs for so long, you know. I really did. Barring a short and entirely disagreeable experience with the original Defense of the Ancients map for Warcraft 3, and a brief stint playing Demigod (which I thoroughly enjoyed, all the while failing to notice it pretty much was Defense of the Ancients) I hadnt touched this genre at all. Heroes of Newerth? Nope. League of Legends? Nah. Dota 2? Good grief, no. There were plenty of reasons for this. First, my initial experience with Warcraft 3s Dota map really was that bad. Second, MOBA communities have a rather strong reputation for being full of complete cockhandles, and I dont deal well with destructive criticism. Third, Im not a huge fan of most pure multiplayer games; I tend to prefer playing solo where I can. It did not appear to be the game for me...

review: Fantastic game. Much longer more intense games, better skill cap and actually requires teamwork and mana control. Oh and you don't get shitlords that scrap their way to 6 build because you actually lose gold if you are bad. Secondly, there aren't runes so everyone is equal at the start and you don't get shafted by picking the wrong runes or not owning some, Hereos are all free, items are cheaper and you can mix and match items from different sers as they go into slots and are cheaper. Finally you don't get summoner spells so people if they get caught, die. They don't flash away and you cant just run up and hit a tower without creeps due to backdoor protection, so rat dota takes skills.

game-hours: 1288.4
review: the mother of all mobas - go for it
game-hours: 266.9
review: I'm new to the moba genre. I once tried Heroes of Newerth, but my first match I got rediculed and ejected from the match for not knowing what was going on, haha. That was a few years ago. My friend recently got me to download League of Legends and give that a try with him. I've mostly been against the moba genre probably from my experience with HoN, but LoL was decent. I had fun. I decided to give Dota 2 a shot since it's a similar game but, in my opinion, better graphics and has Linux support so maybe I could get my brother to play it with me (he has now). I got to say, Dota 2 has sucked me in. The tutorial was very helpful for getting me to understand the genre as a whole better. I'm playing human vs human matches now and do decently well, sometimes being the carry for a team win. It feels to have a faster pace than LoL, which I like, and the learning curve while present, is not overwhelming. The heroes are very distinct and offer seemingly limitless playstyle opportunities.. I've been looking for a game to get "addicted" to for a long time, and although I never thought it would be a moba, Dota 2 has got me hooked. Update: Try to avoid mid-day play times. Lots of bad playing Russians on the U.S. servers during our day, and since they don't speak english, there's no communicating. They don't generally use in game forms of quick communicating either, such as pinging a location on a map. Also most seem to not grasp how to play a MOBA in general. Not sure why they don't stay on easy bot matches because they'll never help win a real match or higher difficulty bot match.

review: An incredible amount of heroes and items combine to form some of the most versatile gameplay I've ever seen. The game is completely free-to-play, with cosmetics, which you'll receive randomly by simply playing, costing very little money. In fact, there are no pay-to-win features. The learning curve is pretty steep, so if you don't persevere through your first few hours, you might just write it off as boring or too hard.

game-hours: 53.0
review: I'm going to be very honest with you, I used to the hate Dota 2, I wanted to spilt it in half with my bair hands. But then I asked a friend recently, "I'm going to give this Dota 2 a try again, can you help me out" because I was getting really bored with the games I already played, over and over again. Then he taught me all the things that I didn't know about Dota 2. Back then before my friend helped me, I used to play as Draw Ranger or whatever her name is, and buy only a healing salve because I didn't know anything about the items. but then my friend started explaining what everything does, and to be honest, It started getting fun, I really enjoyed it. Dota 2 is one of those games where once you really know what you're doing, it gets fun. It has great Co-Op, muiltplayer, you can train with bots, there's basic training which I highly recommend doing, has competetive (ranked) matchs just like CS:GO, there's items that you can put on your Heroes to make them look cool. In conclustion, I highly recommend this game. Don't worry if you're sucking pretty hard at the start, trust me everyone does. But once you start learning the heroes, and pick your best hero, you start to get really good at it, and survive longer. Good luck finding local servers, there's lots of Russians out there playing this.

game-hours: 901.1
review: If youre looking for a reason to commit time to Dota 2  if youre actually reading this review for advice and a critical opinion, rather than to see what score Im going to give the most popular game on Steam  then, first up, thanks for being here. Second, I want you to consider what it means when two grown men accidentally lather each other in regenerative goop. Its gamings equivalent of holding a door open for somebody who is already reaching to hold the door open for you: a synchronicity of kindness that speaks to a deeper shared understanding of the situation both people are in. Dota is a game where you can say the words are you thinking what Im thinking? and be reliably assured that the person on the other end of your VoIP connection actually is. It might have the systems and bearing of a videogame, but Dota shares the social impetus of a sport. Its single environment isnt a map, its a pitch.

game-hours: 1824.2
review: This game is not for people who have less than average control over keyboard and mouse. You would need prior experience with relatively complex games, strategic thinking and perseverence. The learning curve is steep and this game is very demanding for the new players, the community at large is unforgiving and brutal if you are making mistakes as the mistakes you make would affect everybody in your team causing your team to lose. You cannot quit mid-game and the game can go for a long time and the result may not be known till the very end. All this can easily put off many people, but those who pass this rite of passage would enjoy the same things that you hated as a newbie.
game-hours: 19.6
review: As the MOBA genre began to rise to the spotlight of the gaming community. I decided to give it a try. I first tried League of Legends, but was yelled at for being a noob and rage quitted. I thought this kind of behavior was counter-productive, because a gaming commmunity should be supportive of noobs....because even the gaming legends start as noobs as some point in their career. So I got frustrated, and didn't touch MOBA's for a while. However, I'm in deep love in Valve and everything they do, so when I heard about Dota, I got interested. When I completed the tutorial, and finally joined a game, everyone was helpful and willing to assist a noob to a very complicated and intricate genre. I still suck, as I play off a kind of beginner's intinct and not off of a knowledge of the game. However, Dota, with its compelling art style, helpful community, and a touch of Gaben, blew LoL out of the water for me.

game-hours: 57.3
review: Dota 2 is a masterpiece online Real Time Strategy MOBA game published by Valve. The official remake of the original Dota mod, Dota 2 brings over 100 original heroes from the original one. In DOTA 2, players are split into two teams (Radiant and Dire) in head to head PvP action, each consisting of up to five players. Players can choose participate in practice matches versus bots, engage in friendly matches with friends, or form a clan and compete against other teams. Dota 2 has almost all basics of the MOBA genre. Two teams of five players spawn on corners of a map, with several lanes connecting two bases. Two teams should cooperate with each other by the same goal of destroying opponents base which is named Ancient in Dota 2. Players should choose a hero to enter battle with. The AI creeps spawn every 30 second. Heroes will level up by kill enemys creeps and heroes. If players make the last hit of the enemy, they will get gold which players can then use to purchase items in main shop at home or secret shop. Each team has three powerful defensive towers on each lane. When you hero become more and more powerful, you can destroy all defensive towers and finally smash into other teams base to end the game easily.

review: I avoided MOBAs for so long, you know. I really did. Barring a short and entirely disagreeable experience with the original Defense of the Ancients map for Warcraft 3, and a brief stint playing Demigod (which I thoroughly enjoyed, all the while failing to notice it pretty much was Defense of the Ancients) I hadnt touched this genre at all. Heroes of Newerth? Nope. League of Legends? Nah. Dota 2? Good grief, no. There were plenty of reasons for this. First, my initial experience with Warcraft 3s Dota map really was that bad. Second, MOBA communities have a rather strong reputation for being full of complete cockhandles, and I dont deal well with destructive criticism. Third, Im not a huge fan of most pure multiplayer games; I tend to prefer playing solo where I can. It did not appear to be the game for me...

review: Dota 2 is chess for people with a strategic and impatient disposition. It focuses on strategy, if you rush into it without proper thought and planning there is a very slim chance of success. But that does not make it slow paced, quite the opposite. Even if are mindlessly whacking away on some neutral creeps in the jungle you can feel the energy in the air. The only problem I have with it is the community. Entering you're first match is the quickest and most effective way of destroying your soul. The chat is almost always filled with the words "stupid noob" whenever you check it, and I'm not going to get in to the low-priority matches *makes gaging sound*. Apart from that, it is one of the best MOABS I have ever had the fortune to come across. Check Mate.
