review: Dota 2 is, in my eyes, the best game ever made. If it weren't for the overbearing ignorance of the people that play this game, that thrive only on making others angry with said ignorance. This game could have been so much more. That being said, I recommend you get a few of your friends together to play with you. If you can get a group of 3-5 people to play this with. There is no better game. Win or lose, my friends and I have a blast every game. Showing off our skilled plays and laughing at each others blunders. Unfortunately if you are a lone gamer, you will end up with that same type of person in your group often. That one guy that can't play to have fun. His idea of fun is to have the whole team verbally abusing someone for a single mistake for an entire hour long game. That being said, I would give this game a 9/10. The one point deduction due to the MOBA community being a bunch of *ssholes.

review: The Good: Fun, Addicting, Strategic, Teamwork, Dominating, Pub Stomping, Competitive Play, Daily Tournaments and Non Advantage giving item shop (Cosmetic Only). The Bad: Match Making in the skill level bracket can seem to be a bit broken at times. One bad player can ruin the match. Players that disconnect and abandon in 5 minutes. occaisonal 3-5 Minute wait on a match. Other Thoughts: I love DOTA 2 in the strategic gameplay. After all it is a MOBA and a strategy game at best so it requires A LOT of patience and A LOT of good timing, skill, and also great efficient teamwork. Thank you Valve for bringing us such an amazing game!

review: MORE ADDICTIVE THAN HEROINE.
game-hours: 92.1
review: DOTA > LOL
game-hours: 268.0
review: Dota 2 can be tough to get into depending on personal play style, which heroes you start off trying -- took me about a week to find my primary due to the boatloads of heroes available -- and the skill of those you get paired with when you're not playing with friends. It is so very worth it, though. When you're playing a hero you're comfortable with alongside a few good allies even a loss can be exhilaratingly fun as you force your enemy to earn their victory. And of course winning certainly isn't half bad, either. While the nuances of the heroes and whom plays best against whom and where may take a while to sort out, however, the base game is simple to learn. --Runs great even on a laptop. --All heroes playable from the start with new ones added all the time. --Multiple game types provide variety. Tired of the standard "all pick"? Try randomly assigned heroes. Or give "least played" mode a whirl and watch the mayhem play out as you and nine other people all try to play heroes that you don't have the first clue how to use. Prepare to see lots of "oops" and "oh, so THAT's what that does". And "sorry". So, so much "sorry". --Great graphics (especially for the genre). --Music, sound effects and voices get high marks. --Paid items have no effect on gameplay beyond the purely cosmetic. --Pretty much anything that you can buy can be earned for free (at random) from simply playing the game or can be trade for with other players. --Custom huds and announcers can be bought, randomly received after games or traded for to tailor the look and sound of your game to your tastes. What's more, they're shared during matches; If one person in the match owns a given hud or announcer then EVERY person in the match will have access to it for that game. It's not unusual to see nearly a dozen available during a game. --Special holiday game types are always a lot of fun and the developers aren't afraid to really shake things up for them, even adding new ingame items and altering hero abilities. Of course standard matches are still available during these times. --Updates, while very frequent, are usually so small that they rarely take longer than five minutes at most to complete.

Ofcourse there will be dissagreenment with players cause it's competetivity that keeps hatred directing to anyone alse but yourself. I can say that people should pay ABIT more attention to people in your team or at least watch a replay of your own game when you lost or won with quite a bad score. review: As you might know DOTA 2 is a MOBA game, but despite the others games I think DOTA is better. You may ask ''why ?'' , the answer is simple : you can customise Heroes for free and as you want, you can choose your favourite HUD and Announcer.Now about graphics,they are really good even in low quality and imagine if in low quality are that good think how good they can be at high quality.Dota has a darker concept for the Heroes.And at last the gameplay,well,most of MOBA players are saying that is harder.I found it really easy once you learn the items and how that Hero is supposed to go.Maybe I found it easier because is a more strategic game than the other games.I can say only this except Dota 2 I've played 4 other Mobas and the most I've enjoyed is Dota 2. I don't force you to play and like this game ,but I hope you will try at least to play a while and enjoy your play. Good luck & have fun !

review: Wasn't sure what to think about this game when alex introduced it to me. I found it hard to believe that there were league and championships dedicated to play this let alone the hype behind it, though that could be my doupts due to it's link with blizzard. It's very fun and here Valve are just laughing at the bank with the game as people loved the origonal so much. In this case, you might as well just give your money to valve, it's making that much. Very fun RPG, yet hard to explain. You get to pick a character, level him/her/it up and the objective is to destroy the enemy base. Each base creates small creatures called "creeps" and you gain gold for xp by killing creeps and destroying towers. In this case the creeps are red-shirts, running into battle and no real loss when they die. You can download it for free, spectator a match and see what you think. what do you have to lose?

game-hours: 25.5
review: After playing quite a bit of League of Legends, I decided to finally give DOTA 2 a fair shake, and... well, I think I like it. There are some frustrations in transitioning from LoL's mechanics, especially when it comes to Tower/creep aggro (very different strategy than LoL) and overall champion strength, but the more I stick with it, the easier it is to avoid blindly falling prey to these things. I like that all the champions are free, with the ability to pay for non-effective, aesthetic customizations, not to mention the integration with Steam Workshop, to potentially get your own mods in the game. I still favor LoL, but there is a lot to like here, and I look forward to spending more time learning the depths of this game.

review: Nobody cares that no matter what server and language you select there will always be a Russian in your team that speaks his own language and fails hard. Just give them hates and they will be happy with their game loses.... Also, apart from this bad matchmaking that makes you lose 10 games in a row while playing good, the game features an unitard mute system that helps the Russians mute you for an entire week, just because you speak English in an English preference game. There is not a single game without at least one Russian talking sh!t in his f#cked-up language, no matter which server are you playing on. The percentage of deserved punishments of all the players getting punished by the auto punish report system must be less than 10%. How reports are planned to be used in Dota2: -This guy intentionally ruins the game for the other players, REPORT. -This guy flames and insults other players and is very unpleasant to play with, REPORT. How reports are ACTUALLY used in Dota2: -This guy doesn't play this hero the way i do, lol, he is noob, REPORT. -This guy doesn't know russian language, REPORT  BLYAD. -This guy told me what to do, i dont like him, REPORT. -This guy died for first blood, what a feeder, REPORT. -This guy just killed me, i dont like him, REPORT. A while ago developers added "ranked" matchmaking to Dota 2. I've been waiting 2 years for this moment, hoping that when ranked is here it would separate bad players from good players and i would finally get to play with some players that are on my level. COMPLETE OPPOSITE! That so called "ranked" matchmaking is so much worse than the regular bad matchmaking. First of all, this is not even a real ranked system. It has no ranks. Skill is "measured" in numbers. Second - i don't even know why they add a ranked system anyway when it matches people that are rank 4000+ with people that are rank 3500. They couldnt even get it to match ranks close to one another. They even removed the solo que option, so basically you go solo, you play with other solos vs a stacked party enemy, and if thats not enough - the solo teammates you get are 10 times worse than the ones you used to get in normal matchmaking. Getting matched with all kinds of noobs, trolls and sh!t. Playing this game solo is worse than aids and cancer combined! The community is so good that when you disconnect in a game, where you play very good and your team is winning, the enemy team starts unpausing the game for you to get the abandon just that so they can increase their chance of winning or leave the game.

game-hours: 1970.7
review: :)
game-hours: 318.7
review: When you first start to play Dota 2, it becomes kind of annoying to figure out how to play and what to do. After a few matches, you get frustrated and stop, mostly because of the long game times. You come back to it after 2 or 3 days, and you know what the game is about and have a brief idea on how to play it. After some games, its not as frustrating than when you first started. You continue to play for some weeks afterwards, and decide to abandon a match, due to whatever may be the reason - lag, bad hero, didn't win, etc. You realise that there is a low-priority pool, and have to play in it for 2-4 matches. You get annoyed again when you see that you don't receive points to level up due to low-priority. Nevertheless, you finish your matches and continue. In one match, you get abused for doing a wrong move, or just playing badly, and get annoyed once again from the other player. This continues for some time. By 1 -2 months, you start playing a lot better and aren't as afraid to chat to your team - and if necessary, the other team. After more time, you seem to be great at it, but then you lose the nest 10 games. Anger hits you, from the losses of game after game after game, and suddenly you win. You are now a great Dota player, with all the skills required to play perfectly - well at least almost perfectly, apart from the mishaps every now and then. One of the best games I've played.

review: If you want to play a moba game other then League of Legends, then you should wait no longer. Dota 2 is an excellent moba game with alot of exciting events. Unlike League of Legends you can play every hero in Dota 2 without paying for it. You don't have to buy any hero. You can collect cosmetic items for your hero in Dota 2. You are eligible to find items after you finished a game. You can find items like chests, couriers, hero gear/weapons and much more. There is also a ingame shop where you can buy cosmetic items, but this is optional.

review: Hearing about this back when I was still in highschool playing DotA made me very excited. Immediately signing up for the beta. It took longer than one may expect to get a beta key. I got in around the time Invoker was released which is actually perfect timing since I was still honing my skills with him. For a gamer who spent a lot of time in the first game, It wasn't too hard getting into this game. The feeling is there, the looks of the heroes are very similar which is good since going too far from the original concept might be a bad idea. I have invested a lot of time in this since the day I got my beta key. There are two things that worries me first being that the cosmetics shop might get too fancy for a game like this. I fear the day that we get to see them selling a panda outfit for Pudge or a candy cane for Rylai. The last thing is Valve implementing game changing items like a +STR hat or an outfit that makes you invisible to the enemy team for a short amount of time. We'll see.

game-hours: 1172.4
review: It was when I got rejected when I started playing DotA Allstars in Warcraft III, I was hooked to it. I spent 12 - 14 hours playing it every day. I started to get bored by it and day after day, I didn't feel like playing anymore. When Dota 2 was announced, I wanted to get the beta key... but I didn't, and since I didn't feel like playing the original, I spent maybe a year without it. A friend gave me a key to Dota 2, I installed it and played it once, it was my first time getting wrecked so bad that I didn't have the urge to play another game It was then someone broke my heart, I have never been so down in my life. I took so many antidepressants and peer to peer meetings, but nothing works. One day, that same friend who gave me the key, invited me to play. We won and suddenly I felt better. I played and I played a lot. And every game made me feel better about myself and my perspective in life. Dota 2 was there for me when life was too twisted, when reality was too painful to bear. No matter how much I got rejected and how many times I felt alone, Dota was there, to make me happy and make me feel better. Good things has to come to an end so that better things can start, that was when I met her. She fixed the hole in my heart and stitched up the wreckage of the past. For weeks, I played Dota less and less. Right now, I gave all my stuff to my friend that gave me the beta key, a gift of gratitude if you will. So long Dota and thanks for being there for me when I was down and when I want to escape reality 10/10

review: This game is not for people who have less than average control over keyboard and mouse. You would need prior experience with relatively complex games, strategic thinking and perseverence. The learning curve is steep and this game is very demanding for the new players, the community at large is unforgiving and brutal if you are making mistakes as the mistakes you make would affect everybody in your team causing your team to lose. You cannot quit mid-game and the game can go for a long time and the result may not be known till the very end. All this can easily put off many people, but those who pass this rite of passage would enjoy the same things that you hated as a newbie.
game-hours: 19.6
review: As the MOBA genre began to rise to the spotlight of the gaming community. I decided to give it a try. I first tried League of Legends, but was yelled at for being a noob and rage quitted. I thought this kind of behavior was counter-productive, because a gaming commmunity should be supportive of noobs....because even the gaming legends start as noobs as some point in their career. So I got frustrated, and didn't touch MOBA's for a while. However, I'm in deep love in Valve and everything they do, so when I heard about Dota, I got interested. When I completed the tutorial, and finally joined a game, everyone was helpful and willing to assist a noob to a very complicated and intricate genre. I still suck, as I play off a kind of beginner's intinct and not off of a knowledge of the game. However, Dota, with its compelling art style, helpful community, and a touch of Gaben, blew LoL out of the water for me.

game-hours: 516.0
review: A challenging blend of cunning, reflexes, counter-picking, and obsessive arguments over roles, this game will require every inch of anger-management and intelligence you have to succeed. Don't be fooled by the price tag: this game is only free when it comes to material currency. The true cost of this game is your pride, self-esteem, desire to actually go outside, and your respect for foreigners. A nice bonus though is that at least you can use this game to practice speaking Russian or Spanish (and occasionally Portuguese) if you play in the US servers. Now for the good points. This game has an absurdly steep difficulty curve, but that's half the fun of the game; playing different heroes and finding out which playstyle suits you reveals a lot about who you are as a person and can make you realize that you're either a complete  who only ever picks  heroes that only require a single right-click to kill someone or heroes that actually require some skill and strategy to play. If you fit into the latter category, then you earn my full respect. If you fit into the former category, then you'll probably have even more fun than I do at this game because you will give zero  when you insta-pick Sniper (I suffer from severe guilt whenever I choose a carry (except Anti Mage. Anti Mage gives zero s). So overall this game has ruined my life, turned me into an insociable recluse, removed my will to do any kind of work whatsoever, and sapped up every hour of my free time. 12/10 would  es with.

game-hours: 33.4
review: This kind of games is not my cup of tea, in spite of that i like DOTA more and more. Why? Game is not about stupid clicking, how i thought, but if you want to win, you have to strategize and combine special abilities of 5 unique heroes. So if you are not a team player, the game is not for you. The graphics is really nice, but there are some negatives too. The tutorial is very tacky and discourages players from playing more than helps them. The game is very hard and chaotic for newbies. But if you understand to the game a bit, you'll have a great fun. Mainly with a couple of friends. Moreover the game is free to play, so the conclusion is that I recommend DOTA 2.

I started understaning terms like feed feeder last hit kill steal stuffs.. and from then on i have lost my job lost my gf didnt even went to my parents funeral my dog died in the same room i lived thank you DOTA 2 u have given me heavenly pleasures

review: Dota 2 deserves its intimidating reputation, and it probably wont suit you if youre looking to play casually. Theres a huge time investment before you can even enjoy a game, let alone feel competent at it. But once you start to learn its secrets, theres a wild and exciting variety of play here thats unmatched, even by its peers. Its a challenge of knowledge as well as reflexes, and success is a rush. The fact that its completely and totally free to play in the way we wish all free-to-play games could be isnt just one of the most generous propositions anywhere in gaming, it creates a level playing field where skill and cooperation is paramount. May the best team win.

game-hours: 1172.6
review: Dota 2 is a multiplayer online battle arena (MOBA) video game and the stand-alone sequel to the Defense of the Ancients (DotA) mod. Developed by Valve Corporation, the game was officially released on July 9, 2013 as a free-to-play title for Microsoft Windows, concluding a beta testing phase that began in 2011. OS X and Linux versions of Dota 2 were released on July 18, 2013. In most regions, Dota 2 is exclusively available through Valve's content delivery platform, Steam. Each match of Dota 2 is independent and involves two teams, both containing five players and each occupying a stronghold at either end of the map. Located in each stronghold is a building called the "Ancient"; to win, a team must destroy the enemy's Ancient. Each player controls a "Hero" character and focuses on leveling up, collecting gold, acquiring items and fighting against the other team to achieve victory.

game-hours: 2046.1
review: Dota is one of my most played game. If you are familiar to MOBA (Multiplayer online battle arena) Dota is a game for you , it is difficult compare to LoL (League of Legends) no doubt on that . Its a true "play to win" game , purchasable items have no affect in gameplay they are only cosmetic for appearance only . All hero are unlocked unlike LoL you got to pay to unlock or play for hours or days to unlock a single champion . Dota matchmaking "Ranked Match Making" is quite broken. People gets quite frustrated if someone feed's or does some kind of mistake . I know it is quite a reasonable reason , as i did too . You wasted your life 40 min and some random people destroyed the match for you and other's . As goes for gameplay Dota is hard and takes time to learn it is a game for people who are patients . Heroes are quite balanced there are some cool events too like Diretide . its a fun game to play with friends and gets quite annoying too when people does stupid mistakes . There are people who likes to teach noob's like Purge one of my idol in dota 2 scene . New players should check out his guide "Welcome to dota you suck" . My overall rating for dota2 gonna be 9/10 . there are some problem with match making or just my bad luck ? .

review: Best game ever!
game-hours: 2356.1
review: epic
game-hours: 184.0
review: I HIGHLY reccomend this VERY popular game. It is a 5 v 5 battle game where you try to destroy the enemies base while waves of creatures from your team and the other team come. You have to do destroy buildings that attack you along the way to their base, the whole time leveling up your character with new skills and buying items from the shop, each one having a different abillity. With thousands, maybe millions of ways for you to make your character, and with over 100 different characters to choose from, no two games are ever the same. And that's the best part; you do everything you did all over again, while trying to improve your strategy. Unless you want to try a new character. The only downfall of this game is the learning curve. The tutorials that are in the game are okay at teaching you the basic mechanics of the game, there are tons of guides online that help you get a true understanding of the game. There are also reccomended builds for each character, helping you get a better understanding of each character. Once you have that, you are set to go. Hop in a normal game, and pick any of the limited characters selection, and enjoy! After all, while a game can be serious it's still a game, so have fun! I hope to see you sometime soon in a match!

game-hours: 1530.6
review: Dota 2 is an official sequel to the mega-popular Warcraft 3 mod: Defense of the Ancients. For those of you who don't know what that is, it's an extremely competitive Action RTS where you control a single hero unit. You and your team of 4 other players must destroy your enemies' towers, eventually leading to the ultimate objective: a massive building called the Ancient, while also defending your own (That's why it's called DEFENSE of the ANCIENTS). Before you can expect to be strong enough to knock down enemy towers, you need to level up and aquire gold, which you get by killing these AI controlled soldiers, called creeps, that spawn at regular intervals. You need to land the killing blow (last hit) on the creep in order to get any gold from it, which is much harder than it sounds. You need precise timing and knowledge of your hero's unique attack animation in order to be able to get any gold. If you get no gold, then you can't get any items to make your hero stronger. Each hero has their own unique look, unique personality, unique skill set (ranging from super simple to super complicated), unique strengths and weaknesses, and their own unique playstle. It's the player's job to know how to best itemize and control their hero in order to best serve their team. Your hero can be a mage that has powerful spells, a disabler that is great at stunning or otherwise locking down the enemy team, a support that is best at helping other team members, a carry that is great at putting out high damage-per-second with their powerful right clicks, or any combination of the 4. I'm gonna level with you right here. This game is deep. This game is complicated. This game is HARD. It doesn't have a steep learning curve; it has a learning CLIFF. You will likely have next to no idea what you're doing when you first start. You will lose games, but the more you play, the more you will learn, and the more fun you will have. If you don't enjoy games that harshly punish mistakes, you won't get far in this. However, if you like games that reward smart strategy and skillfull play, or if you like deep and super-competitive games with a lot of personality, then Dota 2 could be exactly what you're looking for. Play it (Unless you suck...)

game-hours: 4841.8
review: Theres an adage that the Dota 2 community often quotes when someone identifies themselves as a new player. Welcome to Dota 2! They say, with open arms, before concluding with, You suck. They're not wrong: for the first dozen hours or so, you'll be bombarded with too much information and an often unforgiving community of extremely competitive players. But if you persevere, Dota 2 becomes one of the most rewarding and tense team-based multiplayer experiences anywhere in gaming. It's an achievement owed to uncompromising depth, a ridiculously generous free-to-play model, and the great features developer Valve has built up around it. Valve's artists deserve praise for a crisp and readable style that, after some practice, makes it possible to tell what's going on even in a massive brawl where both teams Dota 2 July 9. 2013 Dota 2 promises to take the unique blend of online RTS and RPG action that has made Dota popular with tens of millions of gamers and expand upon it in every way.  Much More Phill Cameron Says Easier-to-learn MOBAs Super Monday Night Combat Awesomenauts League of Legends of five colorful fantasy characters collide and cast spells at once. However, credit for the intimidatingly complex design of Dota 2 belongs to the original Defense of the Ancients mod (known as DOTA) for Warcraft III, which kicked off the MOBA genre. Valve (after hiring on DOTA's key developers) has copied that formula almost to the letter, and as a result Dota 2 has become notorious even among its MOBA peers for its difficulty  and thats totally justified. Its a double-edged sword that leads to both a terrifying introduction and a world-class competitive game at the highest levels. As such, you should not expect to have fun your first day playing... or even your first week. That sounds like a cardinal sin of gaming, but theres method to this madness. In short, Dota 2 is a deeply layered construct of systems, and to survive you need to understand every single one and how they interact with one another. Everything from learning to work as a member of a coordinated team to the counter-intuitive practice of killing your own AI units to deny the enemy experience points and gold theyd get from doing it themselves, and understanding the effects of hundreds of complex abilities like Bloodseekers Rupture (which deals huge damage with every step you take) is a big barrier to entry. Even figuring out which of the 102 heroes (and counting) fits you best is a time-consuming challenge. Initially, youre thrown into the deep end to flounder, trying out any hero that makes the slightest bit of sense. The selection is bewildering: playing as Riki with his permanent invisibility from level 6 on is an obvious choice, as it's hard to kill what you can't see. Drow Ranger, perhaps, with her obscene damage the instant she unlocks her "ultimate" ability at level 6, and her slowing Ice Arrows that enable both escapes and setting up a kill. On the more complex end of the spectrum you have choices like the armour-manipulating Templar Assassin, or the incredibly mobile Storm Spirit, who can dart around the battlefield and avoid damage by simply not being in the wrong place at the wrong time. On top of that there are well over 100 items to choose from within each game, each with their own ways of manipulating and enhancing your stats and suite of active abilities. Your learning has just begun when you've settled on what roles, heroes, and builds suit you best  you also have to adapt based on what other players choose. If the other team plays a Riki, you need to compensate with an emphasis on detection. Go up against Bloodseeker and his hideously powerful Rupture will force you to carry around a Town Portal Scroll to get home in a hurry. To grasp the subtleties of how heroes interact and fight you have to do more homework on the different kinds of damage and how theyre mitigated; how to prevent one type of spell from affecting you, and when you use that countermeasure; how the different kinds of aggro work, and when you need to manipulate them; the timers (which aren't made visible), and how to optimise your play around them. Even after all that, to avoid being caught at a disadvantage you must be taught the nuanced techniques that can make or break games, which Dota 2 seems to almost belligerently hide from new players. Tricks like pulling a group of neutral monsters out of their home so that a new group can spawn to effectively double the rewards are never hinted at. This forced me to read and educate my outside of Dota 2, which had the positive effect of introducing me to the player community and making me feel like a part of it. It's almost like an oral tradition that binds together a tribe. This is a balancing system that could only exist in a game where everybody has access to all heroes, and Valve wisely obliges. All of Dota 2, including its growing cast of 102 characters, is available from the moment you complete the all-too-brief tutorial. And that delicate system can only survive if the items for sale have zero effect on gameplay. Again, Valve has come through. Only cosmetic enhancements, almost all of which are created by the community and held to a very high standard, and tournament goodies (such as tickets for viewing live events) are for sale. Theres not a single paid advantage that could have the slightest impact on the in-game balance, and thats an amazing situation unrivalled among Dota 2s closest competition. Pretty much everything I've praised Dota 2 for, outside of being totally free, is taken directly from the outstanding original mod. Where Valve has taken initiative to make Dota 2 a significantly better experience is in everything surrounding it, including improving the pre-game matchmaking interface, supporting the community of professional and avid players, and even allowing artists to create and sell cosmetic items on the Dota 2 store. Perhaps most important are the steps Valve has taken toward taming the hyper-competitive community. Besides matchmaking, guilds, and a wide variety of different game modes, the things that Valve hasnt done are just as noticeable than the things it has. For example, theres no concede button to throw in the towel on a losing match, and though you earn a matchmaking rank to ensure you're placed competitively, it's not visible to other players. If withholding those features seems like a bad idea on the surface, their sacrifice was not in vain  it prevents irritable players from dropping out of a match at the first sign of defeat, or when they're teamed up with people whose stats don't meet their exacting standards  a real frustration in other MOBAs. LIkewise, Valve recognized that less is more when it comes to unlockables. Theres no progression outside of the game that will have the slightest mechanical effect inside of it. Without artificial goals to aim for, the matches are left with a strong and refreshing sense of fairness and purity, where everything that can influence success or failure is right there on the battlefield and in your head. In my personal experience, Valves ideas work. I've played for over 1,000 hours, and my encounters with people unwilling to act decently towards their fellow players have become increasingly rare over the course of Dota 2s development. It has never been more friendly than it is now  though thats a relative comparison. Even with these enhancements, the best way to play Dota 2 will always be with a team of four friends. IGN-
game-hours: 1263.8
review: A 6 or 7 line review just won't do this game justice. Dota 2's learning curve is pretty steep but once you learn the basics, which can take 5 to 15 matches, it's rewarding experience that's all about teamwork and playing your role correctly. Dota 2's social features are cutting edge and designed for great casual, hardcore and competitive play. The controls are tight and responsive while dedicated servers on multiple locations allow for almost no noticeable latency. It's free to play but people won't use their wallets for tactical advantage because all items are purely cosmetic. Really impressive game and my personal Game of the Year 2013.

review: A dynamic system to entertain the mind, train your brain/memory, enjoy great pvp and develop leadership, teamwork, foresight, calculation and prediction skills. A varied cast of characters each with their own skill set and a wide range of items to help with customization of the way you want to play. An interesting community ranging from great, co-operative players and impressive enemies, to the lowest gamer quality which require you to develop patience and restraint. If you consider picking this game up, remember, there is a high learning curve, therefore you must be prepared to fall and rise again in the never-ending battle between the Dire and the Radiant. Good Luck, Have Fun

review: Started getting into MOBA's and its a very fun game to check out
game-hours: 1606.6
review: I never liked games like league of legends or smite, but Dota 2 is a whole new story. It is absolutely a great and addictive game to play. The character selection is massive compare to LOL. It is more complicated than League of Legends, so it will take more time learning the game. Some differences between the two games are: 1) couriers that bring you items instead of walking to base to get it 2) you have to buy Town scrolls to teleport back to base. 3) you can "deny" creeps. ( killing your own creeps so your opponent gets less gold and exp) 4) if you die, you lose gold and is harder to comeback from 5) in game voice chat 6) "pause" key to halt the game if you need something. ( anybody can unpause regardless of who paused it) Based off my experience in this game, i haven't encounter much "ragers". I get the occasional one here and there, but not as often as League of legends. Update: Ever since i started doing ranked matches, there have been more "ragers" and non-english speakers. It was frustrating at times, but I got over it. If you don't like the bad side of this game's community, i suggest getting friends to queue up with you. Don't have friends that play dota? Make new friends during your games. You'd be surprise at how nice some people are in games. Don't worry too much about the Haters. Let them hate, while you enjoy a good time playing dota. Online games will always have some haters, especially games that involves a lot of teamwork. Based off my experience in this game, i haven't encounter much "ragers". I get the occasional one here and there, but not as often as League of legends.

game-hours: 1456.7
review: Before March I didn't know much about Dota 2, I heard about it and that was all. And then that day came when in March I launched Dota 2 for the very first time. I was excited, didn't know much what to expect and was kinda looking forward to finally play it. Now at this point I must also say that a had a friend who usually plays MOBA and RPG games and was trying to persuade me to start playing Dota 2 with him and was always saying him maybe next time. Well fast forward 2-3 months I got an Invite to Dota 2 Beta. I said lets at least try it and we will see. Together with me was that friend( on skype) and then I accepted my first match. I was hyped, the screen showed simple but kinda cool logo of Dota2 and then the hero screen came, I didn't know much and hero list was big so I clicked on Random hero and I got Timber. Even though I had my friend with me I sucked bad... hehe I sucked really bad and feed for like 7 games straight. My friend who was my coach those first games really helped me and with the help of him and tutorial videos on youtube I started to familiarize myself to Dota and for those first games even though I was really bad I was starting to get to know the basics of the game. And yea even though I sucked those first game I was enjoying myself :D It didn't bother me if someone called me a noob as long I was enjoying myself. Games went I was starting to play more like the game wanted me. I played a lot of game since then and i'm still enjoying myself when I have with me people who actually knows we need a support and we can't always have 4 carries :D It's true game is a little bit hard and you need to have someone with you who knows dota or you need to at least watch those tutorials on youtube. but when you learn this things game really opens up and you're set to play :D I also really like cosmetic items and the way the dota allows people to create some great looking items and hopefully put them into the game. Pro scene is also great, I watched TI 2013 and I saw my favorite team win :D Games sometimes turn really crazy and that's the charm of dota. This game is really great when you get to know things. So new players don't lose hope, watch some tutorials, play safe and you should be set. I rate this game 9/10.

game-hours: 730.6
review: So. Many. Heroes.... But the tutorial helps. Suggest you take Dragon Knight, Skeleton King or Drow Ranger and play vs bots a few times. Learn what items to buy. Learn to run away constantly. You should never die! You should rarely even get hit by the creeps (the army of monsters that endlessly comes out of the enemy base). Your job is to level up quickly and efficiently so you're ready to face the enemy heroes when they hit 6th or so and come to murder you. When you graduate to real players, everything you've learned about enemy hero behavior from the bots goes out the window but hopefully you've learned to play your heroes pretty well by now. This game is a blast with friends vs bots or real people if you and your friends are accomplished. The community used to be pretty nasty/unforgiving but they have improved and the developers have made such a beautiful interface/tutorial system it's very inviting now. Highly recommend for anyone.

game-hours: 2374.4
review: What is Dota 2? Well, I've gone at length describing the title before, but I felt like doing something different this time considering the reviews are actually going public. Dota 2 is the ultimate soul of the AoS genre mixed with good old trial and error, along with down right sadistic requirements. DotA is by far and large the game I've spent the most time playing, clocking in thousands of hours over the years. Dota 2, while receiving less of my time, is also in the same boat, as it's basically the same game with an identity crisis, having problems deciding whether it wants to be a carbon port of the original or put into a septic tank and mixed with Barbie dress up mechanics. What is Dota 2? Well, it is a game of you and 9 (+) other poor sods being put into a world of relentless battles in order to defend that giant structure in your base like that's supposed to make sense. The game is entirely multiplayer driven, and there're those 4 other players on your team that you have to deal with on the regular basis, whose vocabulary consist mostly of "", "hue" and "sodding Russians". Team work, knowledge and strong mechanics are what you need to be successful at this game, and the game gives you bugger all but (in)expensive pixel hats as consolations prize for wasting the majority of your teenage years controlling video game characters. I don't mention any names because the game has sod all story and the lore is compiled of a twelve year old boy's power fantasy who has been reading too much of Lovecraft to mess the lore up but not enough to tie it all together. That said, the game is certainly worth your time, god forbid it being actually productive. Its very core concept builds up the true vision of the original: a straight forward walk towards frustration, filled with toxicity, lack of a sense of progression and any rewarding experiences except for playing the game itself. It is an absorbing, glorious and tight game tied into strategy and clutch decision makings, the qualities seriously lacking from the modern gaming industry. Furthermore, the game is completely free to play, and while its developer's release line ups resemble that of a clothing store, these frisks in no way interrupt the core game experiences nor do they hamper the fairness of the game in any way. The philosophy is clear and it is great: you come in the game the same as everyone else, the only winning point is your team's collective effort. Outside of the gameplay itself, the spectator and competitive aspects are built in and are great. I would even go as far as calling it the best in the business right now. Of course, as someone who cannot take a look at the 'professional' farce as anything but a cheap laugh on a cold winter night when I'm at home staring at my monitor screen hoping to stop procrastinating, it doesn't affect me a whole lot. Do not get me wrong, there are plenty of people in the scene that I like and respect, but the whole notion never seemed particularly interesting to me, especially for a game like this. Outside of this and the aforementioned clothing line, there's the giant learning curve that hits in the face of every player picking up this title for a quick bite. It is unforgiving in the sense of feeling like having a drill shoved down your throat while trying to juggle a pair of knives and a baseball bat. Have fun.
game-hours: 1922.9
review: Fact: Dota 2 ruins lives. I'm writing this in the hope that others can learn from my mistakes. I used to be a respectable human being like yourself, until I started on Dota. Now I play 4 hours+ a night and spend most of my income on capes for a night elf archer. It all started one afternoon when I was happily playing Skyrim. I was sent a message and an invite to the beta of Dota, or 'Defense of the Ancients (see? I don't even know where Sweeden is on the map yet I know what that stands for!) For anonymitys sake let's call this person 'Mark.' Now Mark seemed like the decent sort, well dressed and spoken with a healthy spring in his step, not the kind you would expect to pray on the weak. He told me that him and a group of others were gonna try it and that it was all perfectly safe. The first time seemed fun and before long I was playing every night. Now some people had warned me about the dangers of becoming addicted but well, you never really think it will happen to you do you? But it creeps up on you, slowly at first, maybe one HUD skin here, a courier there but it doesn't stop at that. Soon you need a full set to get the same thrill that a random drop would have previously given you. You start hanging around the dis-reputable parts of the internet trading in seedy back ally's with Russians just to complete the clothing set of a character you don't even play as. It's no way to live... Unfortunatly it's too late for me. But please, who ever you might be, Stay. Away. From. Dota! --- Above was a message from 'James' a recovering dota addict who works with young people to help them with their addiction. If you have been affected by Dota, feel free to call the anonymous MOBA addicts helpline: 0800 11 22 33.

review: The latest effort in making a full-fledged game out of a Warcraft III mod. DOTA 2 places you and up to 9 other people in an arena like environment where a never ending war between good and evil is taking place. After choosing around 100 heroes (with more coming) and dozens upon dozens of items to help give your hero the edge, the game does not stop giving you something to strive for, whether it be mastering the latest hero release, or finding the perfect build for your role of choice. Install as soon as humanly possible.

game-hours: 1587.6
review: Dota 2 is hard, but there's a huge reward for those who commit. On the surface, the game is a like-for-like reproduction of the genre-creating (and still updated) Defense of the Ancients modification for Warcraft III, now transferred into Valve's Source engine. The game's punishing design is sometimes enough to drive you up the wall, but it's worth sticking the hours in: success in Dota 2 is about learning to effectively juggle both the broad strokes and finer details.

game-hours: 2003.5
review: Dota 2 is the most addictive and fun to play games from valve since team fortress 2. Dota 2 is a competitive and rewarding game which can overcome other MOBA games. Dota 2 has reached all my expectations and more. I honestly cannot think of any downside to the game. Characters are well built, the sound effects and soundtrack is amazing, the characters comments is the best of all the games of the same kind. It's said Dota has a high learning curve which is true, many usually give up within the first 5 hours of game play due to the difficulty and usually turn to games like HON and LOL. To all those Dota 1 players I am glad to say that everything is exactly the same item wise and character skills, this makes it easier to quickly get used to it. In the beginning you might find the game a bit confusing and accidentally keep clicking the old short-cuts for your ulti since Dota 2 adopted the Q W E R format, but once you get used to the new interface you will just feel the awesomeness that once let you get hooked to Dota. Most of the Dota players started to play LOL waiting for the release of Dota 2 if you are one of those then it will take you a longer time to get used to last hits and the range of the characters but when you do, it will all be worth it, so don't give up. Plus the game is going to be Free 2 play what more do you need :).

review: Definitely recommended. I've spent countless hours lost in the pixels of the Dota world, moving along 3 lanes, through lush jungles, a long river and the pit of big , humongous and sweet-deprived keeper of the Aegis. It's great to play with friends and to rib each other constantly, but also extremely rewarding playing with random strangers in pubs. Your own individual skill, micro prowess and language prose come second to your abilities to communicate effectively with teammates and also co-operation as well as co-ordination. Game and map awareness comes after many a pub-thrashing received, but it all adds up to the experience garnered. Also, you get to learn many languages of the world by its most basic form, and the form I truly feel is the right way to go about learning a language, curse words and the way they laugh. Always a good time =D

game-hours: 1346.4
review: The best MOBA game in the world
game-hours: 934.6
review: DOTA 2 is easily the best MOBA in existence and possibly one of the best games ever made, yet it's also one of the most unforgiving. It's hard, the learning curve is steep, and it takes a lot of time and practice to become proficient at each role and with different heroes. However, if you can become anything more than mediocre with a few heroes, it's one of the most rewarding gaming experiences you'll ever have. Those are the good parts. The bad part is this game has the worst community of players I've ever seen, hands down and it's not even close. Imagine if you-know-who's /b/ board was a video game, then throw in every ignorant and racist teenage troll, mixed with a huge chunk of Russians and Spanish kids who can't speak English - that would put you somewhere in the realm of this game's player base. You cannot play this game unless you have a thick skin, and I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone who hasn't been around "the online gaming community" for a long period of time. This game can and will get worse than anything you've seen or heard on Xbox Live. Having said all that, Valve is making some smart moves lately in their attempt to clean up and weed out the worst of the worst. They have "punishment pools" you get banished to for acting like an idiot and for players who can't stay connected for 40 mins at a time. There is a report feature that works and gets people muted for days on end, and in general the game is a lot "cleaner" than it was during beta and early release when I started playing.

game-hours: 309.3
review: This game is definately worth the price: FREE. The community is friendly and willing to teach if you're new to the genre. If you've played any RTS game in the past ten years, you'll be able to figure this game out pretty easily. With around 100 heroes and counting, this game has a great deal of variety and will always be challenging. Unlike many free to play games, this game's micro-transaction model is aesthetic only. There are no huge powerups or big weapons or purchases of in-game currency that will give the payer an edge over others. This game is very much the antithesis of the "pay-to-win" model.

game-hours: 2269.3
review: Such a strategic game filled with a lot of mysterious beauty from the four corners of the map, which indeed made it phenomenal and remarkable. You get to learn and experience a lot of things with friends and random strangers all over the continent you are situtuated, thus, enhancing your social development. The game requires a strategy to accomplish the goal and wise decision-makings for the welfare of your team which enhances your intellectual development and psychological development. The game could also possibly develop your emotional development as an axiom once said, "The more you get stronger, the more you get kinder." It only has one common goal and that is to destroy all defending towers of the opponents to possibly destroy their throne, but the beauty of it doesn't merely lie on accomplishing those, but also the clashes of your heroes in between small fights and the bond you had with the players that is. Its uniquely created and highly upgraded from its prerequisite, Defense of the Ancients (DotA) which made it a lot more catchy and addicting! From the doodads and props of the map, its terrains, its features, all of it is absolutely fascinating and intriguing! Makes you crave for more games every each other game. I just loved the game just as much as every DotA player do, so I made this review even though it's kinda nonsense just to test my knowledge of the game as well.

game-hours: 1590.6
review: Dota 2 is a multiplayer action/rpg/strategy rage filled competitive video game (remake of dota from warcraft3) that pits you and 4 others against 5 russians from EU west in a fight for cyrillic chat superiority. Choose your CHAMPION from a growing list of CHAMPS, each with their own set of overpowered abilities, level up , buy items and advance towards the enemy in order to destroy their base and fish in a fountain for the final 5minutes. all the while creating new friendships with your foreign bretheren who may give you endearing names such as  and noob. You are accompanied on your journey of keyboard rage by an ever lasting team of minions who will valiantly kamikaze themselves into enemy towers and heroes, whilst carrying with them a sack of gold which you must pillage from them once they have become bloody and battered enough to feel the merciful blow from their champion overlords. Once the battlefield is strewn with enough bloody carcasses of slain minions and foes you will become strong enough to destroy your enemies ancient building and most likely be rewarded with an epic treasure chest. And remember, if you're having fun playing dota2, you're playing it wrong!

review: Excellent game. After playing the first (and best) DOTA, LoL, HoN and a few other MOBAs, I found this one to be the best. Not only is it the incredible graphics, intense gameplay or the classic feel of old DOTA, but the online gameplay is incredible. The only problem I had with this game was the amount of updates and the fact that other countries choose to play where they will not be best, such as Russians playing in the South African server, not that I am complaining, that is just my opinion. PROs: - Excellent Gameplay - Great graphics - Classic feel - Simple use - Kept old DOTA's characters, gameplay and items CONS: - Not a great matchmaking system - 5-10minutes inbetween matches - Too many updates - Updates are too large All Round: A great game which I have been addicted to for the past month.

game-hours: 1150.3
review: Dota 2 has got the be the world greatest game. And it's free! On top of it being free it also doesn't follow the 'Free to play but Pay to win' kind of thinking, but instead follows the team fortress 'Free to play and pay to look better'. This game is all about skill and teamwork, so there's no possibities of cheating or getting smashed by those who empty their banks into this game as that's not at all how it works. You also can practise against bots with bots, or online against bots of a range of difficulties. This is great for begginers to actually figure out how to play, find a hero that's best for them and understand the whole workings of the game. Even if you're not new it is still a magnificent feature for strategy practise and to play with heroes you've never played before to see what they're like without getting killed a lot by those online. The games community is great, with minor exceptions. And is an easy way to learn other languages as people from all over the world play. only bad side is for begginers it's a big learning curve, loads of heroes to choose from with all different attributes, abilities and styles, plus the shop. But at least you have vs bots to practise so it doesn't matter.

game-hours: 2954.1
review: DOTA 2 has a really steep learning curve if you aren't familiar with other tower defense style games, which is discouraging initially. However it becomes very addicting once you've learned the vast system of items and characters that give the game great depth and replay value. I highly recommend playing cooperatively with experienced friends as it is a very team oriented play scenario and it will help you find your niche. There are so many characters and ways to play each of them that there is somebody for every personality. One drawback is that there is only one map, which gets monotonous. It is a very well devised map, however! Share

game-hours: 3398.2
review: The game is fun. There is no doubt about that. It is fun and frustrating at the same time. You have to work as a team. You and you alone aren't going to decide the outcome of a match. Unfortunately, it seems to have most of the same trappings as Valve's other F2P game, Team Fortress 2. The items introduced into the game have little to no quality control. Thankfully, we have yet to see items that affect the stats of the characters themselves. Dota 2 is one of the best MOBAs in the genre, but far from the most popular. Dota 2 allows you to play all of the heroes that the game offers without spending antyhing, but similar games only allow you to play a small, rotation free hero pool. You must then purchase the each hero individuall with in-game currency or real money. Dota 2 is far better in this sense. Dota 2 also seems to be a bit more high-level than other games in the same genre. This can be both good and bad as it allows for you to reach a higher skill ceiling, but it can be discouraging to new players. The community can be vile and the punishments for "leaving" a game are strict. If you have connection problems or have other commitments that won't allow you to spend updwards of an hour at the computer, I don't think that this is something you could enjoy. Since it is free, I'd recommend you pick it up and give it a try. I will update this review to be more in-depth at a later time.

game-hours: 1049.5
review: Each match of Dota 2 is independent and involves two teams, both containing five players and each occupying a stronghold at either end of the map. Located in each stronghold is a building called the "Ancient"; to win, a team must destroy the enemy's Ancient. Each player controls a "Hero" character and focuses on leveling up, collecting gold, acquiring items and fighting against the other team to achieve victory. Overall, this game is a very intense and full of war occurrences, spell caster, magic and physical damage, even the absolutely stunning built-up for every each heroes. This game, Dota 2, is the best multi-player game available on the market yet...!

review: Don't get me wrong Dota 2 is a great game, however when you start playing this game you will be beaten with cludgels the size of The empire state. As you play somewhat 20 hours of it you start to figure out how ot actually play. It is heavily rewarding and enables you to enjoy yourself alot more. It takes skill and intelligence to play well and you always learn new things. There are so many phases of skill you go through, this being said as you get constantly better you change in the way you play, you think faster and your reaction time decreases. Its one of those things you do not realise unless you review how you have played. Also i recommend not playing this list of heroes as they require no skill to play and are exceptionally over powered: Sniper ..... his ult is op aswell as his range. Ursa ..... applies fury swipes to target (increases damage done to target after every consecutive hit) Drow ranger ..... Slows you like seriously 50% slow on hit of a maxed out frost arrow. Riki ..... Permenant invis, you get used to being safe while invis but beware if someone actually knows how to play dota they will buy wards or a gem of true sight and then you will be useless Viper .... slows you even more than drow axe .... just is generally op Don't play them as you feel amazing when you do well with them then again they take no skill to play, should be nerfed. League of Losers is easier than dota but less rewarding! One of the best games on steam.

game-hours: 1218.7
review: Dota 2 deserves its intimidating reputation, and it probably wont suit you if youre looking to play casually. Theres a huge time investment before you can even enjoy a game, let alone feel competent at it. But once you start to learn its secrets, theres a wild and exciting variety of play here thats unmatched, even by its peers. Its a challenge of knowledge as well as reflexes, and success is a rush. The fact that its completely and totally free to play in the way we wish all free-to-play games could be isnt just one of the most generous propositions anywhere in gaming, it creates a level playing field where skill and cooperation is paramount. May the best team win.

game-hours: 1584.1
review: At first, I was completely unaware of how I should've played this game. But thanks to the community, I learned a few crucial steps to becoming a good player. I'd like to share the steps I've learned with the rest of the community. Step 1: During my first game, people told me that playing on an English version was a terrible idea, and they recommended me to go make it Russian. That increased how well I understood the game by tenfolds. Step 2: Always buy Mask of Madness and Divine Rapier. My team told me that these two items would make me win every game I played. Although it took me a bit of time to farm the Divine Rapier, the Mask of Madness made me attack super fast that I didn't need any other item. The Divine Rapier also made me hit very hard. If your team doesn't approve of this, they're just jealous that they didn't think of this build. Remember, the more rapiers, the better. Step 3: The last step is to pick these few heros if you're starting out: Meepo: His Ultimate ability is to make more meepos. More meepos=More fun. Chen: Even though he's labeled as a support, just go for the typical MoM Divine Rapier build on him. Works every time. Invoker: His Q, W and E give Strength, Agility and Intelligence respectively. His R is useless, so don't even both with it. All you need is the stats. And those are just a few of many helpful tips on how to become a good player in dota! I hope this review helped!

review: Dota 2 is hard, but there's a huge reward for those who commit. On the surface, the game is a like-for-like reproduction of the genre-creating (and still updated) Defense of the Ancients modification for Warcraft III, now transferred into Valve's Source engine. The game's punishing design is sometimes enough to drive you up the wall, but it's worth sticking the hours in: success in Dota 2 is about learning to effectively juggle both the broad strokes and finer details.

game-hours: 1.1
review: A good twist on a MMO mostly focused on strategy. This game is playable by a wide range of players due to it's different playing style for each character. Whether you are a supporter role for a team or the leader or the pusher. All of them offer unique gameplay styles. The objective though rather simple is rather hard to achieve in fact and can lead you to racking your brains to think of the best way to destroy the enemies base. This game forges camarderie among players as each player in the team have to work with each other and support each other with the different skillsets they each have. I strongly recommend you trying this game for a classic game twisted into something fresh and renewed, it's worth a try and most certainly will find a playing style in there to suit you.

game-hours: 286.1
review: GGWP
game-hours: 1650.5
review: What can I say? After 1000 hours I still feel unwelcome in the obnoxious community and still get absolutely stomped, but I just cannot put this masterpiece down. Defense of the Ancients was a pioneer of the Moba genre and it's sequel remains a strong contender with the likes of Smite and League of Legends. Dota 2 offers a pool of over 100 absolutely free heroes and both a casual and competitive approach. However you choose to play the game you'll be met with an array of toxic, cussing and hateful individuals who will trash talk and rage at you for the simplest mistake. A thick skin is necessary to obtain full enjoyment out of Dota 2. Ignoring the savage community, Dota 2 has perhaps the most engaging, entertaing and satisfying gameplay ever. It feels amazing to initiate a succesful teamfight or to just win a close game. Most heroes are balanced meaning most victories are owed to the skills of the players, however a keen sense of mechanics knowledge is mandatory due to the game's reliance on different damage types and various other integral factors. Whilst it can be difficult as a new player, persistence and resilience can introduce you to many hours of fun. For the best possible experience, playing with friends will both save you from hateful people and allow you to synergise your strategies. Dota 2 is free, so you have nothing to lose from buying it except maybe your social life.

game-hours: 335.2
review: Over 300 hours of yelling in my mic a mix of Russian, Spanish and English. -------Actual Review------- (Work in progress) Background of game: DOTA originated as a warcraft 3 mod, which can still be played. Then Valve took this game, re-masterd it, and made it one of the biggest MOBAs (But still only has a fraction of LOL's player base). The Good: -Valve's got lots of money, and so does the player base. This causes some darn large prize-pools, which are also contributed to by the players. The Bad: -Addictive as hell. -About 1/10 players speak a different language and don't care to learn english. Examples include: Russian, Spanish, and Portuguese. Other Problems: -Warcaft DOTA had a lot of heroes which were ported into DOTA 2, causing a lot of copyright problems between Blizzard and Valve. Gameplay: First games should be with bots, and maybe after 10 games you should start playing with people. If you don't know what to buy, valve gives you suggestions based on your hero in the buy-menu. If looking for a guide, you can find one in the top right.

review: If you're going to spend any time playing either this and/or League of Legends, this is a far more interesting use of your time. Here are a list of pros and cons: Pros: -Heroes have integrity and character -Hats -Carries don't build the same things as each other -There is no designated "jungler" role -Game mechanics don't change to accommodate bad players -Game mechanics don't change to accommodate immature players -volvo -Holiday themed game modes in which you can obtain hats -Game mechanics don't change to accommodate whiny players -Hat trading -gaben -Victories are highly satisfying -The game is highly cerebral -Half-Life 3 confirmed -Also, hats Cons: -The matchmaking system is suspicious -Russians not playing on the Russian servers As you can see, the pros clearly outweigh the cons. By this metric, you should most definitely play this hat simulator, I mean, game.

game-hours: 445.4
review: The bringer of peace. The face of torment. The destroyer of worlds. DotA 2 is a strong game due to it's ability to command different levels of skill. But such as a game can yield a high skill ceiling, such a thing can also lead to several downfalls. DotA has a tendancy to bring out the worst in some folk that might otherwise be pleasant enough outside of the game's clutches. Toxicity in mobas, however, is not in DotA alone, nor only in mobas themselves. As any game goes, the people you face will ultimately vary and it's up to you as the player on who you should focus on and how you should adequately respond. Focusing on the warmer characters and ignoring those who aren't will produce a better gaming experience for all involved and create better teamwork, and that's important in a team-based game. That aside DotA 2 has fantastic gameplay and, if you're willing to put in the time, you will gain more from the experience. It's free. It's accessable. It's certainly worth a try.

game-hours: 2048.9
review: If you're just a mere casual player looking for something to that you can use to kill time, then turn back now as Dota 2 is not the game for you. Dota 2 is unrivaled when it comes to balance, and competiveness. You will seldom come across a video game that requires as much cooperation and teammork, and let's not forget thlat is also unrivaled for being brutally unforgiving. New comers will undoubtly struggle, and the learning curve will sure drive away many new players but those who prevail will have experience one of the greatest possible experiences they will come across in gaming. Dota 2 is all about tactics and strategy. Everything you do or purchase from the in-game shop will have a significant effect on the outcome of the game, for good or worse. It is also where creativity with unconvential hero drafts or unorthodox item builds can either make you or break you, this is what makes Dota 2 so great. Getting into every aspect and detail into the game would require more than just a few paragraphs as this game is so immese and in-depth. I am writing this review almost with under 2,000 hours of gameplay under my belt, and I am not ashamed to say I am no master or expert, to the contrary actually I am just an average Dota 2 gamer who still questions himself, will I ever stop playing this game? Will Dota 2 ever get boring and old? I doubt it.

review: AWESOME .
game-hours: 327.2
review: Dota 2 is a multiplayer online battle arena (MOBA) video game and the stand-alone sequel to the Defense of the Ancients (DotA) mod. Developed by Valve Corporation, the game was officially released on July 9, 2013 as a free-to-play title for Microsoft Windows, concluding a beta testing phase that began in 2011. OS X and Linux versions of Dota 2 were released on July 18, 2013. In most regions, Dota 2 is exclusively available through Valve's content delivery platform, Steam. Each match of Dota 2 is independent and involves two teams, both containing five players and each occupying a stronghold at either end of the map. Located in each stronghold is a building called the "Ancient"; to win, a team must destroy the enemy's Ancient. Each player controls a "Hero" character and focuses on leveling up, collecting gold, acquiring items and fighting against the other team to achieve victory. Development of Dota 2 began in 2009, with the hiring of DotA developer "IceFrog" to serve as the sequel's lead designer. Dota 2 was praised by video game critics, who lauded it for remaining faithful to its predecessor while also increasing the level of production quality, as well as for its engaging and rewarding gameplay experience. However, Dota 2 was criticized as having a steep learning curve and inhospitable community. The game has become the most played on Steam, with daily peaks of over 700,000 concurrent players.[5]

game-hours: 717.0
review: Of course I would recomend this game. It is the standard for team based multiplayers. Everything about it is very well refined. This game is very challenging, and its learning curve is steep. Do not play this if you are looking for something easy. I can also say that without friends this game is not very fun. The best way to play this game is with a full 5 player team of all people you know well in real life. Communication is key. A well earned victory with your friends in this game hoever is the most satisfying victory that you will experience in a videogame. And that is the trade off. It is so difficult and one win is won on a road paved with hundreds of failures, but when you do win... Its everything :) If I were to critique anything about this game it would be that there isn't a 3v3 game mode. I feel like it would be a boon to the game to have a shorter game type that requires less players to play. This would allow for more fun in those times that you cant afford to put a lot of time into it.

review: I have spent more time with DoTa2 than any other videogame. Having logged over 1.5k hours, I can say with confidence that DoTa2 is the most rewarding game that I have ever played. DoTa offers a sense of community and acomplishment unlike any other game. Long 5v5 battles force players to communicate deeply - and winning these long battles makes the hard work even more rewarding. Although the MOBA genre in general has a VERY steep learning curve, once immersed in the world, it's hard to break out. DoTa2 is something of a magical videogame and amazing community packed into one F2P experience. Thanks valve.

game-hours: 249.7
review: Dota 2 is by far the hardest to learn game I have ever played. However, it is one of the most fun. If you're new to Dota, and you want to get better, you have three options: 1. Practice bot games over and over using a ton of guides and such until you can consistantly beat unfair bots no problem. 2. Play a ton of games with more experienced friends (this way is the most fun). Make sure that they're close friends, because they will teach you, but if you don't listen to them and keep dying or buying bad items or whatever, they'll hate playing with you. So listen to your teachers! 3. Play games on your own and try your best, and end up being yelled at by four different people at the same time (9 if you're lucky). But if you get through the learning phase, this game becomes amazing. It's an awesome strategic game to play with friends. You'll win some and you'll lose some, but it's free and fun, so what the heck.

game-hours: 549.0
review: Great game . addictive
game-hours: 2192.4
review: Dota 2 is a game that started back in War Craft 3 as a mod but ended up it's own game because it was such a great idea. The competitive scene has plenty of content if you are interested in that (would recommend Beyond The Summit for ProDota stuff) and playing the game is thrilling. The learning curve is massive and very very brutal but once you start to climb, you realize that you aren't the only one and after having clocked in over 1000 hours i feel i still have room to improve and that makes this game worth playing even longer to see what your limits are. If you played Dota 2 a while ago and quit playing i don't recommend this game because it has changed substantially in the 6.82 Balance Patch basically turning our beloved Dota 2 into Dota 3. But, of course if it doesn't bother you that the game has been shaken to the foundations or you are new i definitely recommend this game to you because it is immensely fun and you can poor endless hours into it and still get pwnd like a noob by a fed bloodseeker T-T Good Luck and Have fun with this game, i highly recommend it to you dear reader and i thank you for listening to my opinion. Oh yeah, and remember: It's just a game and people will try to aggravate you, just mute them ;) - Me :D

review: NC game
game-hours: 768.7
review: I made a recommendation for DotA 2 a while back, but that was when I was awful at the game. Now, that I am not awful, I can accurately explain why this is one of the greatest games I have ever played. (Good = +, Neutral = o, Bad = -) + Over 100 Unique Heroes, and, the roster is still growing! + Thousands of items to fully customize your Heroes + So many Heroes, that there is a great chance you will find your favorite one. + Hilarious announcers. o Some people of the community are asshats + So many ways to make your playstyle unique with in-game items. + Many online modes that will keep you busy + Extremely time consuming to level up, so, a level 30 isn't something you see often. Until recently of course, they had an update which make's it extremely easy to level up from 1-10. Which I dislike, I feel as if we earlier players deserve compensation, but it's not that big of a deal. + Everytime you level up, you have the chance to unlock rarer items. + Everytime you level up, you get awarded an item. + Items can be found just by playing ranked/pub matches. + Portal Pack/Stanley Parable Pack + Game is updated constantly, fixing bugs, and adding new content. + ABSOLUTELY FREE! o Addicting, which in turn will make you spend your money on in-game content. Which is of course your fault and in no way the game's fault, but it's still like a hypnotic spell. + Absolutely beautiful visuals. + Very strategic gameplay. + Great soundtrack. o Getting started can be a pain, unless you have the time, or a friend to help you. + Doesn't publish your losses, which can occassionally ruin troll's. + Even if you win or lose a match, Battle Points are handed out equally, and drop rate is the same for everybody, so, losing really isn't too much of a big deal. But, as of recent, big Battle Point Booster's are around, I have a friend who is level 7 but only has 10 game's played, I remember when I was level 7, I had around 100 game's played... it's quite annoying. + Valve allows users to create items for the game, and if your item is picked, you will get payed by Valve, and your item will be put in the game. + Matches you with people your level, so you won't be fighting a level 55. + Even if you don't notice, after playing this game, you will gradually get much better, sadly, you won't be able to notice in ranked/pub matches, since you get matched with people your level. Play this for a while, and fight one of your new friends, you will surprise yourself. + Warcraft inspired Heroes, which is incredible, since I was a big fan of Warcraft. If you don't like games that involve competing, or you easily rage quit, this isn't the game for you. But, if you're fine with rage quits, and difficult opponents, you will love this game, it's fun, and, even after 600+ hours of playing, I am still doing things I have never done before... DotA 2 Deserves 10 Kats all over it's pretty little Ancient... out of 10

review: hello
game-hours: 1175.9
review: Dota 2 is a very extensive and deep game but this depth and complexity in my opinion means a great ceiling of fun. I really enjoy this game. You can play as an oblivious person with your oblivious friends and derp around the game and have lots of fun trying to bash each others heads in while trying to break that coveted ancient, but be warned; if you enjoy this game you might want to try playing online. Playing online is a different experience ENTIRELY. Team work becomes so much much oh ever so much much so muchly much much more crucial than before (Dr.Suess reference XD) If you are still playing with your group of friends though at this point that should help a lot. But like many people (myself included) you will be in games where you are alone amongst 4 strangers All of whom have their own agenda seemingly (it is not ALWAYS like this.) you will try your best to help your team win but it will inevitably end in a couple of your teammates being head-strong idiots who fed the other team (let the other team kill them to many times) then the fed team is big bad and bulky, then you lose. There are games where you and your team will work together and you will DESTROY!!! that will not always be the case so enjoy it when it happens and get over it when it doesn't. If you plan on being great at this game be prepared to spend hours researching what the items do; all of the recipes, heroe's skills (especially ultimates), and watch games of people who are good (I reccomend Purge he's on YouTube.) If all this seems overwhelming it's because this game can be CRAZY overwhelming however it has potential to be CRAZY fun! The bottom line is what you put into this game is what you will get out of it; at the time of this review i have 270+ hours in-game and I still feel relatively noobish; I have been having fun this whole time however. So if you don't feel like putting away crazy amounts of time into a game then i suggest you get 1-9 friends who also don't know how DOTA works to get this game and just play private games together and have a BLAST because it is quite a lot of fun. A little about me. I played DOTA 1 the Warcraft III mod as a late-comer with 1 other friend game after game and we derped PLENTY But through those games I learned about the stats and recipes of about 90% of the items in the game, giving me a pretty sizable advantage. I could have made this review about ten times longer but then it would have been a guide... (it already kind of is) 10/10 by the way this game is great!

review: Wasn't sure what to think about this game when alex introduced it to me. I found it hard to believe that there were league and championships dedicated to play this let alone the hype behind it, though that could be my doupts due to it's link with blizzard. It's very fun and here Valve are just laughing at the bank with the game as people loved the origonal so much. In this case, you might as well just give your money to valve, it's making that much. Very fun RPG, yet hard to explain. You get to pick a character, level him/her/it up and the objective is to destroy the enemy base. Each base creates small creatures called "creeps" and you gain gold for xp by killing creeps and destroying towers. In this case the creeps are red-shirts, running into battle and no real loss when they die. You can download it for free, spectator a match and see what you think. what do you have to lose?

game-hours: 264.4
review: Dota 2 is popular free-to-play game by Valve. Its fanbase is huge, with an average of 500,000 players online at any one time (and nearly 8 million players monthly), and growing. The game has team-oriented gameplay, a large number of uniques heroes, and exciting tournaments with ludicrous USD$10 million prize pools. Dota 2 has something to offer to most gamers, from those who prefer strategy and tactics, to those who like aggressive twitchy action, and even those who enjoy agriculture.
