review: I can't feel my legs.
game-hours: 45.5
review: I guess......
game-hours: 1002.0
review: Dota 2 is a masterpiece of competitive gaming. Endlessly replayable due to its incredible depth, the game truly never gets old. Continuous support ensures that the game never gets stale, with a constantly changing meta. Dota 2 has a steep learning curve, but once you find your way, there is no other game like it. Few games are as painful to lose, but inversely, as satisfying to win, as Dota 2. Unparalled strategic and mechanical depth ensure that no player will ever be as good as they can be in any one game, yet it is incredibly satisfying to strive for perfection through continued play. Strategy is deeply involved before you even "begin" the game, with hero selection, all the way through to the end of the match. Certain heroes work particularly well against others, are weak to others, and coordinate exceptionally with others. This is due to the array of unique abilities that each hero possesses, and the role they fill on their team. Once the game begins, players must coordinate with their team members in order to play most effectively. This is done in combat, as well as in what item purchases players decide to make. Strategy is extensively involved in item purchases, combat, and positioning. Players must constantly react to the game in order to play effectively, and since no game is ever the same, the experience is always different, making each game a fresh experience, and one that I will continue to enjoy for as long as I can foresee.

game-hours: 1172.6
review: Dota 2 is a multiplayer online battle arena (MOBA) video game and the stand-alone sequel to the Defense of the Ancients (DotA) mod. Developed by Valve Corporation, the game was officially released on July 9, 2013 as a free-to-play title for Microsoft Windows, concluding a beta testing phase that began in 2011. OS X and Linux versions of Dota 2 were released on July 18, 2013. In most regions, Dota 2 is exclusively available through Valve's content delivery platform, Steam. Each match of Dota 2 is independent and involves two teams, both containing five players and each occupying a stronghold at either end of the map. Located in each stronghold is a building called the "Ancient"; to win, a team must destroy the enemy's Ancient. Each player controls a "Hero" character and focuses on leveling up, collecting gold, acquiring items and fighting against the other team to achieve victory.

There is not a single game without at least one Russian talking sh!t in his f#cked-up language, no matter which server are you playing on. The percentage of deserved punishments of all the players getting punished by the auto punish report system must be less than 10%. How reports are planned to be used in Dota2: -This guy intentionally ruins the game for the other players, REPORT. -This guy flames and insults other players and is very unpleasant to play with, REPORT. How reports are ACTUALLY used in Dota2: -This guy doesn't play this hero the way i do, lol, he is noob, REPORT. -This guy doesn't know russian language, REPORT  BLYAD. -This guy told me what to do, i dont like him, REPORT. -This guy died for first blood, what a feeder, REPORT. -This guy just killed me, i dont like him, REPORT. A while ago developers added "ranked" matchmaking to Dota 2. I've been waiting 2 years for this moment, hoping that when ranked is here it would separate bad players from good players and i would finally get to play with some players that are on my level. COMPLETE OPPOSITE! That so called "ranked" matchmaking is so much worse than the regular bad matchmaking. First of all, this is not even a real ranked system. It has no ranks. Skill is "measured" in numbers. Second - i don't even know why they add a ranked system anyway when it matches people that are rank 4000+ with people that are rank 3500. They couldnt even get it to match ranks close to one another. They even removed the solo que option, so basically you go solo, you play with other solos vs a stacked party enemy, and if thats not enough - the solo teammates you get are 10 times worse than the ones you used to get in normal matchmaking. Getting matched with all kinds of noobs, trolls and sh!t. Playing this game solo is worse than aids and cancer combined! The community is so good that when you disconnect in a game, where you play very good and your team is winning, the enemy team starts unpausing the game for you to get the abandon just that so they can increase their chance of winning or leave the game.

game-hours: 318.7
review: When you first start to play Dota 2, it becomes kind of annoying to figure out how to play and what to do. After a few matches, you get frustrated and stop, mostly because of the long game times. You come back to it after 2 or 3 days, and you know what the game is about and have a brief idea on how to play it. After some games, its not as frustrating than when you first started. You continue to play for some weeks afterwards, and decide to abandon a match, due to whatever may be the reason - lag, bad hero, didn't win, etc. You realise that there is a low-priority pool, and have to play in it for 2-4 matches. You get annoyed again when you see that you don't receive points to level up due to low-priority. Nevertheless, you finish your matches and continue. In one match, you get abused for doing a wrong move, or just playing badly, and get annoyed once again from the other player. This continues for some time. By 1 -2 months, you start playing a lot better and aren't as afraid to chat to your team - and if necessary, the other team. After more time, you seem to be great at it, but then you lose the nest 10 games. Anger hits you, from the losses of game after game after game, and suddenly you win. You are now a great Dota player, with all the skills required to play perfectly - well at least almost perfectly, apart from the mishaps every now and then. One of the best games I've played.

review: If you want to play a moba game other then League of Legends, then you should wait no longer. Dota 2 is an excellent moba game with alot of exciting events. You are eligible to find items after you finished a game. You can find items like chests, couriers, hero gear/weapons and much more. There is also a ingame shop where you can buy cosmetic items, but this is optional.

review: Hearing about this back when I was still in highschool playing DotA made me very excited. Immediately signing up for the beta. It took longer than one may expect to get a beta key. I got in around the time Invoker was released which is actually perfect timing since I was still honing my skills with him. For a gamer who spent a lot of time in the first game, It wasn't too hard getting into this game. The feeling is there, the looks of the heroes are very similar which is good since going too far from the original concept might be a bad idea. I have invested a lot of time in this since the day I got my beta key. There are two things that worries me first being that the cosmetics shop might get too fancy for a game like this. I fear the day that we get to see them selling a panda outfit for Pudge or a candy cane for Rylai. game-hours: 1172.4
review: It was when I got rejected when I started playing DotA Allstars in Warcraft III, I was hooked to it. I spent 12 - 14 hours playing it every day. I started to get bored by it and day after day, I didn't feel like playing anymore. When Dota 2 was announced, I wanted to get the beta key... but I didn't, and since I didn't feel like playing the original, I spent maybe a year without it. A friend gave me a key to Dota 2, I installed it and played it once, it was my first time getting wrecked so bad that I didn't have the urge to play another game It was then someone broke my heart, I have never been so down in my life. I took so many antidepressants and peer to peer meetings, but nothing works. One day, that same friend who gave me the key, invited me to play. We won and suddenly I felt better. I played and I played a lot. And every game made me feel better about myself and my perspective in life. Dota 2 was there for me when life was too twisted, when reality was too painful to bear. No matter how much I got rejected and how many times I felt alone, Dota was there, to make me happy and make me feel better. Good things has to come to an end so that better things can start, that was when I met her. She fixed the hole in my heart and stitched up the wreckage of the past. For weeks, I played Dota less and less. Right now, I gave all my stuff to my friend that gave me the beta key, a gift of gratitude if you will. So long Dota and thanks for being there for me when I was down and when I want to escape reality 10/10

game-hours: 37.2

game-hours: 43.8
review: This is an excellent game. For Warcraft 3 lovers, who have played the original DOTA, this will blow you away. There have been a lot of improvements to the overall gameplay, balancing, item modification, hero selection, and overall purpose to the game. For players new to DOTA, not only is this game free to play, (with some purchasable items in game that have no effect on the outcome of the game, just cosmetics), but it is very easily learned, a lot of fun, and it is a game that can be played in about 45 minute intervals. The DOTA Profile is also a great feature, leveling you up as you gain experience so you can be matched with players that are relatively the same skill level you are. It also includes some fun information, like who your most successful heroes were, your win/loss record, and items that you want to feature. Coaching/Spectating is a great new feature from the original DOTA Warcraft 3 Map, because you can have experienced players come in and watch you play, coaching you. You can set it to where you can only listen to that person and no one else, providing personalized instruction. Hero Build/ Item Build is awesome, you can literally create customized builds for your heroes that can be used through the entire steam community. If you're learning a hero you've never played, selecting a community build is a great way to learn. There are many other features, and many other reasons to give the game a try. Whether your an old hat at DOTA, or looking for a change of pace, this game is for you.

review: When I first played the game, I was confused and didnt understand the strategy behind MOBAs. Frustrated, I quit the game for a year. But I came back to try again, I learned from my mistakes and took in some advice, along with watching a few videos on the basics of the game. Once I had a grasp of it and knew what I was doing I began to enjoy the game MUCH MUCH more. The game has great Lore, simple controls, and an easy-to-use shop. This game is also truly F2P, yes, you can buy items from the market that use actual real-world money, but these items are PURELY cosmetic, and do not give you an advantage whatsoever. Most of these cosmetic items can be earned by simply playing the game, which in my opinion makes it truly F2P. This game also has excellent Steam integration, with free guides to help you learn the game. In short, this is a fantastic game that I intend to spend many more hours playing. I fully recommend this title to gamers of all skill levels.

game-hours: 2346.7
review: Dota 2 is a game about social criticism. There are many different valuable classes needed to survive the coming battles, but of course, everyone is tempted to just opt for the top 1%. If there is indeed a working class, it will nearly starve, barely able to afford even basic necessities like boots, in order to sustain the greed of the upper class. There is, of course, a middle class, which is basically just failing to keep up with the upper class while scared  to end up like the lower class. All of this is happening in the vanguard of a great big war that is allegedly happening because the two factions like different tree colors, but it's really to make more money to buy more stuff that allows you to wage more war to make more money. The emulated class system is supported by severe language barriers and the game does a good job of making you hate even your closest friends, eventually. 10/10.

game-hours: 561.4
review: Two teams of five fight across three lanes. Three specific types of shop sell sixty different magical items. There are more than a hundred characters to play, and an unknown quantity still to come. Eight types of specific role that you can play as part of your team. Its safe to say that Dota 2 is a game of numbers. Despite Valves best efforts to ease players in gently, Dota 2 is an inherently overwhelming game. The first few hours of this MOBA are relentlessly bemusing, but after that the difficulty curve becomes smoother - giving you a tangible sense of how youll get better. Each match tends to last somewhere between 30 minutes and an hour, offering vast amounts of entertainment if youve got the time. Lengthy games can cause frustration when things arent going well, however, which is the main source of Dota 2s rep for breeding a virulent strain of internet . Losing isnt frustrating if youre learning something new, and getting to know every character will take roughly 100 hours. Its also worth mentioning that you really get to know them - the vocal work and animations are superb, giving Dota 2 some of the best character design in gaming. Over the next 50 hours it becomes clear that Dota 2s complexity isnt pointless PC-RPG-posturing. Every character, skill, and item serves a purpose. Its a pleasant surprise to find that its depth doesnt damage the clarity of the design. Gold buys you items and XP levels characters up, but in contrast to the messy fashion in which the RPG genre has incrementally evolved, Dota 2s purity shines. Whilst too impenetrable to entice non-savvy spectators, theres no doubting the games quality as an E-sport. Youll need knowledge, skill, and a smidge of spider-sense. Friends to learn with are a must, and dont be deceived by the lack of a pricetag: Dota 2 will cost you hundreds of hours.

game-hours: 2453.4
review: So, with nearly 1200 hours on record, I feel like I should share my thoughts. First and foremost, this game will make your family love you less. Your mom, significant other, child, pet etc will need you for something and your response will be, "I can't pause this". You will be accused of putting video games before loved ones because they don't understand that if you retreat to the fountain to kiss your kid goodnight, all of your Russian teammates will yell at and report you. They'll treat you so badly for having a family that the whole match will be ruined and you'll start to hate DOTA. Your family cannot understand that. At its core, DOTA is a team game made up of three kinds of people. People that want to play as a team, Peruvians and Russians. The server you select has no bearing on which of these types you will meet. If you play Captain's Mode or Captain's Draft, you typically avoid the latter two types, but the game is very competitive and unfriendly for new players. Basically, you have to learn to play with idiots. You'll turn into a racist, you'll yell at someone in a language they don't understand, you'll be blamed when your  teammate runs into a 1v5 fight and loses because you should've been there. Eventually, you will become comfortable with a few characters and decide to explore Ranked games or Captain's Mode. You'll be paired with people that speak your language. Games, tactics, and plans will come together. You'll make friends. You'll start to queue together on a nightly basis. You'll form a team. You won't be great, but you'll have fun.... tons of fun. As long as you didn't need that family we talked about earlier. DOTA 2 is an emotional roller coaster that will transform you into a racist and require Zoloft. 10/10

game-hours: 1794.2
review: Most people on steam have probably heard the name of this game countless times now. So let me give you a short and simple review on it. Get it. Now that that's out of the way try and use the tips I am about to give you so you can get he best possible experience that this game has to offer. Dota 2 has a steep learning curve meaning you can't just jump in there and expect to know what you are doing. When you first launch the game as of recently you are taught how to play through the tutorial the game has to offer. Actually pay attention to this or it will bite you in the  when you are actually playing. Once you get that over with you're probably going to say to yourself "Ok I think I get what I am doing, let me play online matchmaking" Here's one simple answer for you; NO. Dota 2 requires a team effort, and what I mean by a team effort is that if 1 person does something it will affect the team. If 1 person does bad, the team will take the toll of that 1 person. So if you are going straight into matchmaking with almost no experience, you are most likely going to die a lot, get yelled at, close the game, and never come back. Trust me I should know because that was my first experience with Dota 2. Now what I do recommend you do is either practice by yourself or with friends in an offline bot match. That way if you do bad you don't feel bad for perhaps costing the team the game. Not only is this better, as you keep playing you will learn more and more about the game. Try and find someone that is experienced to help you understand the game and help you progress in skill for it. Once you feel that you are more knowledgeable about the game you can go ahead and do perhaps coop bot and then onto the traditional matchmaking where it is 5v5 team fights. Dota 2 is one my favorite games to date. The fact that I have this gem another chance makes me lucky. Try to follow the tips I provided in this recommendation and I guarantee you that you will not be dissappointed with Dota 2.

game-hours: 823.8
review: An evolution of the Defense of the Ancients (a spin off from Warcraft 3). It has the signiture and feel of its predicesor with a much added kick in graphics and almost everything else. The game tries its best to branch out from its older version and I must say, it is succeding with every step it makes. The biggest thing though which separates it greatly from the the old DOTA is the market place and the punishment system, which punishes players for leaving the game unfinished and for being rude to other players. It is this system which separates and cements this game into something of a higher level. The only downside is that you need a gaming computer with high end specs in order to enjoy the game 100 percent. While most first world country won't have any problems with this, players living in third world countries might have an unfair disadvantage when playing online. Overall, the game raises the bar for other games out there in this genre.

game-hours: 268.0
review: Dota 2 can be tough to get into depending on personal play style, which heroes you start off trying -- took me about a week to find my primary due to the boatloads of heroes available -- and the skill of those you get paired with when you're not playing with friends. It is so very worth it, though. When you're playing a hero you're comfortable with alongside a few good allies even a loss can be exhilaratingly fun as you force your enemy to earn their victory. And of course winning certainly isn't half bad, either. While the nuances of the heroes and whom plays best against whom and where may take a while to sort out, however, the base game is simple to learn. --Runs great even on a laptop. --All heroes playable from the start with new ones added all the time. --Multiple game types provide variety. Tired of the standard "all pick"? Try randomly assigned heroes. Or give "least played" mode a whirl and watch the mayhem play out as you and nine other people all try to play heroes that you don't have the first clue how to use. Prepare to see lots of "oops" and "oh, so THAT's what that does". And "sorry". So, so much "sorry". --Great graphics (especially for the genre). --Music, sound effects and voices get high marks. --Paid items have no effect on gameplay beyond the purely cosmetic. --Pretty much anything that you can buy can be earned for free (at random) from simply playing the game or can be trade for with other players. --Custom huds and announcers can be bought, randomly received after games or traded for to tailor the look and sound of your game to your tastes. What's more, they're shared during matches; If one person in the match owns a given hud or announcer then EVERY person in the match will have access to it for that game. It's not unusual to see nearly a dozen available during a game. --Special holiday game types are always a lot of fun and the developers aren't afraid to really shake things up for them, even adding new ingame items and altering hero abilities. Of course standard matches are still available during these times. --Updates, while very frequent, are usually so small that they rarely take longer than five minutes at most to complete.

game-hours: 492.5
review: A very good game, excellent graphics.
game-hours: 2319.6
review: DOTA 2 was my first introduction to the MOBA genre and I have to say it can be very addicting. Games like Starcraft scared me away from 4X RTS games because of the level of micro-management it requiremed, so I was a bit hesitant to play this game. DOTA 2 however has little to no micro-management depending on the heroes you choose. It provides a wide variety of different play styles for different player preferences. Later I heard about Heroes of Newerth and League of Legends, so I thought I'd try them out. I played a couple games of LOL and knew that it just didn't provide the depth of gameplay I got playing DOTA 2. I quickly uninstalled it. Heroes of Newerth provides the same depth I would say, but the experience just didn't feel as smooth as DOTA 2. Maybe it had something to do with the pacing of the game. After uninstalling HoN, I've never looked back. DOTA 2 is here to stay. I highly recommend playing this game. It's quite fun if you spend a little time to get into it. My advice is to take it slow, learn how to play, and expect to fail a lot in the beginning. Remember, you can't get better at DOTA 2, you can only suck less.

game-hours: 2219.7
review: What point is there in recommending a free to play game? An interested reader can now simply download the game and dispense with the opinions of stranger. Of course, Dota 2 is not the only game that is free to play, and the genre is rather notorious for its steep learning curve, so this recommendation is intended to answer a a slightly different question: is it worth the time? Largely, yes, but maybe it's better to consider some of the features that might turn the curious player into a fan of the game or not. The process of learning can be rewarding in and of itself. Valve has put a lot of work into breaking down the learning curve into managable pieces, though it is by no means complete. Perhaps the best analogy is with chess: The tutorials and bots will teach you the mechanics of the game, but this only accounts for a very small part of what we generally consider 'knowing chess/Dota'. Of course, much like in Chess, the community has provided guidance and past games to study and consider on the path to mastery. Furthermore, in the relatively brief period of time I have played the game, there have been substantial changes to heroes and the map itself, meaning that the game continues to provide rewards for thinking on your feet instead of rote memorization. This is not to say that certain 'core builds' are irrelevant (they're important, and you can set them up as presets in the game itself or simply use someone else's), only that there are great rewards to be found in understanding *why* those builds are important. For what it is worth, I have found the guides produced by Purge to be a great introduction to thinking about the game, and his conduct during games (usually) serves as a model that the community would do well to follow. Which brings me to the first major stumbling point of Dota. Despite tremendous efforts on Valve's part to keep the toxic elements of the Dota community to a minimum: you will play with extremely unpleasant people who will not make the game fun. There are number of ways this can happen. People can simply have terrible attitudes and do their best to make you feel awful. Put them on mute immediately. But once you get past the initial stages of learning, you'll develop a certain sophistication for play style. I cannot think of a game that has teamwork as a more essential component to it. Games played with strangers are not assured to have the expected level of cohesion and, at low skill levels such as mine, the chances of the mythical 'ideal game of Dota' are vanishingly small. The problem is that this is simply not a matter of 'other people.' You will ruin games for people through not being prepared, or having an off day. You may also find yourself becoming short tempered, or hostile to your teammates due to the frustration of the game. It is uncomfortable to admit how many chat messages have been started in anger, only to be shortly abandoned after a moment's reflection. This could explain the challenge of the Dota community's attitude, but, whatever the causes, it is a factor that an aspiring player will need to deal with. There will be a point where the bots cease to be fun to play against. At that point you will begin playing with people. At that point you will have lots of bad games for reasons of attitude, team composition, or all of the above. *BUT* the games that are good pay off so much more than all those challenges combined and magnified. Even in the dregs of pub games, to hit that magical team that just clicks without needing to be told the basics, or doesn't go for selfish picks in hero selection, is an absolute joy that anyone should get to experience at least once before throwing in the towel. There are incremental rewards as well: being able to view some of your old replays and see how far you've come. Supporting so well that weak carry was still able to snowball and win. Even the realization that, by instinct, you made a tactical decision that meant the difference between an escape or a death, all these things put a little wind in the sails and motivate continued time in the game. Finally, being a Dota player has opened me up into new avenues of entertainment that I simply didn't appreciate before. With events such as The International I can see this game played at the highest skill levels. I finally have a toe hold into being able to appreciate the interest in eSports. More importantly, as a player of the game, I can appreicate the skill in those games to a much greater degree than any other spectator sport. Despite the vast gulf of knowledge and talent between myself (and most players) and professionals, I feel like playing Dota gives me a better understanding of the decisions and plays that are being made in high skilled games, than a better knowledge of skating or puck handling would give me of a professional hockey game. The dynamics of the skill levels are entirely different, but Dota 2 will always have the same mechanics for everyone and the same map, meaning you have the exact same resources (human capital aside) at your disposal as the pros do. In essence, this is only a game I could recommend to someone who was willing to put in the time, tough out the hard times (and there will be hard times. I write this during a time where I'm particularily frustrated with the game and partly to answer the question why I bother for *myself*), and who genuinely finds enjoyment in the process of learning. There is absolutely no shame in not wanting to take up a game that asks this kind of commitment, and the claims of how 'hardcore' a gamer is usually boil down to an individual trying to assert their preferences over the greater population. If you don't have the time, if you don't feel particularily thick skinned, if you don't like the idea of 'working' at a game, then I do not recommend Dota 2. But for those who find value in the journey, fire up the download and start playing.

game-hours: 624.5
review: Pros: With 100ish heroes and a massive range of items this game will keep you playing for hours trying to discover the best combination of items for each hero, the best combinations of complimentary heroes for a team and to uncover stacks of aesthetic items to win. There are different game types to allow for practice with bots, ranked matches for more skilled players and tournaments for full teams who wish to compete. When you get a good team the atmosphere is really good and victories feel like a real achievement. As well as the standard game types there are often updates to bring players seasonal game types such as Frostivus around Christmas. It has a simple interface which makes controlling your character and communicating with other players easy without compromising control of either when multitasking. As for graphics, you can play the game on a very standard computer at low graphics without losing any of the experience and at high graphics it is visually pleasing but just as good. Unlike many other multiplayer games you can only buy aesthetic items from the shop using real world money. This prevents people with stacks of cash boosting themselves to become the best players based on cash and not skill (a common complaint in MMORPGs and other platforms). Cons: As with any massively multiplayer game there are many cons, these mostly revolve around the players. When finding a match you are given the option to set a language preference so you can speak with people who understand you. This function is next to useless. I have played over 300 matches and I'd say only about 100 of those were with a team of people who spoke English well enough (when specifying English in the language preference) to lay out or understand complex tactics. There are designated keys for simple commands to try and overcome the language barrier but this is often not enough for skilled players. Next is the reporting function. While you only receive a penalty for multiple reports, it is often the case that petty people will report you for winning games or simply for killing them. As far as I know these reports are not checked by moderators or not to a high standard because I've been perfectly polite and ended up being thrown in the sin bin (Low priority matchmaking) for having a winning streak. The matchmaking system is highly frustrating, it is not based on skill (some say this is a good thing... but it REALLY isn't) so if you have one bad person on your team it brings the entire team down. The servers are always crashing in some way, shape or form which can continue for days. Finally, there are a great number and variety of people who play DOTA. I'd like to say that most of these people are good natured but I have very often experienced people making comments of a nationalist, racist, biggoted, childish (etc) nature towards other players. Everything from "go and kill yourself" to "I had your Mum last night". It's a keyboard warrior dominated world to say the least. Conclusion: It's a really good game worth hours of fun and defintely worth downloading because it's free (can't complain too much about game/server faults with it being free as they do get fixed). BUT the community are mostly unforgiving, cruel and will flame you if you're not up to par (that's if you can understand what they're saying). If you're unable to ignore people when they're being vicious then get real life friends to join you. Otherwise avoid like the plague as the frustration will give you an aneurism.

game-hours: 1485.6
review: Dota 2 is a MOBA (multiplayer online battle arena) title developed by Valve and Icefrog, the creator of the original Warcraft III mod from which this game was based. Dota plays like a RTS (real time strategy) that pits two teams of five players against each other: each player can choose from a large pool of playable heroes, each with his/her own primary stat, role and gameplay. A match of Dota 2 revolves around both destroying all the enemy buildings, exspecially the huge and sturdy ancient in the very end of each base, and killing off non playable units and other players in order to gain experience to acquire new abilities or improve the ones already gained or the stats and gold to buy powerful pieces of equipment in order to make the various heroes even more deadly Dota 2 is a rather complex videogame: being a successful player involves around having a good knowledge of the various heroes abilities, how to react quickly to various events and how to plan ahead in order not to give the enemy team too much of an advantage. Each match is rather unique and unpredictable, with comebacks being very rare, but possible nevertheless Dota 2 is rather infamous for its playerbase, which is arguably the most rude, angry and elitist wannabe I've ever seen. Expect the other players to quickly point out your mistakes, sput insults and menaces at you for percived errors and get upset at you for not following what each team mate believe you should do at any given second of the match. It's also worth mentioning that the in-game report system that Valve designed in order to isolate the most unbereable members of the community rarely works, and it's instead used by rude players in order to silence or just plain sabotage other players they disagree with. Another great issue is that, while Dota 2 features language specific servers, most players won't join the proper servers, but will instead opt to join all the servers available and get mad at other people if they don't speak their native language. Russians players have become quite infamous for such practice If you can manage to stand tall of all the abuse described above, Dota 2 can reveal itself to be quite the interesting experience and generally a good multiplayer game to play
